prologue.stagedir: Enter the Ghoaſt of Andrea, and with him Reuenge.

speech.speaker: Ghoaſt.
speech.line: When this eternall ſubſtance of my ſoule,
Did liue impriſond in my wanton fleſh:
Ech in their funƈtion ſeruing others need,
I was a Courtier in the Spaniſh Court:
My name was Don Andrea, my diſcent
Though not ignoble, yet inferiour far
To gratious fortunes of my tender youth:
For there in prime and pride of all my yeeres,
By duteous ſeruice and deſeruing loue,
In ſecret I poſſeſt a worthy dame,
Which hight ſweet Bel-imperia by name.
But in the harueſt of my ſommer ioyes,
Deaths winter nipt the bloſſomes of my bliſſe,
Forcing diuorce betwixt my loue and me.
For in the late confliƈt with Portingale,
My valour drew me into dangers mouth,
Till life to death made paſſage through my wounds.
When I was ſlaine, my ſoule deſcended ſtraight,
To passe the flowing ſtreame of Archeron:
But churliſh Charon only boatman there,
Said that my rites of buriall not performde,
I might not sit amongst his paſſengers.
Ere Sol had ſlept three nights in Thetis lap,
And ſlakte his ſmoaking Charriot in her floud:
By Don Horatio, our knight Marſhals ſonne,
My funerals and obſequies were done.
Then was the Feriman of hell content,
To paſſe me ouer to the ſlimie ſtrond,
That leades to fell Auernus ougly waues:
There pleaſing Cerberus with honied ſpeech,
I paſt the perils of the formoſt porch.
Not farre from hence amidſt ten thouſand ſoules,
Sate Minos, Eacus and Rhadamant,;
To whome no ſooner gan I make approch,
To craue a paſport for my wandring Ghoſt:
But Minos ingrauen leaues of Lotterie,
Drew forth the manner of my life and death.
This knight (quoth he) both liu’d and died in loue:
And for his loue tried fortune of the warres,
And by warres fortune loſt both loue and life.
Why then ſaid Eacus, conuay him hence,
To walke with lovers in our field of loue:
And ſpend the courſe of euerlaſting time,
Vnder greene mirtle trees and Cipreſſe ſhades.
No, no, ſaid Rhadamant, it were not well,
With louing ſoules to place a Martialiſt,
He died in warre, and muſt to martiall fields:
Where wounded Heƈtor liues in laſting paine,
And Achilles mermedons do ſcoure the plaine.
Then Minos, mildeſt cenſor of the three,
Made this deuice to end the diﬀerence.
Send him (quoth he) to our infernall King:
To dome him as beſt ſeemes his Maieſtie.
To this eﬀeƈt my paſport ſtraight was drawne.
In keeping on my way to Plutos Court,
Through dreadfull ſhades of euer glooming night:
I ſaw more ſights than thouſand tongues can tell,
Or pennes can write, or mortall harts can think.
Three waies there were, that on the right hand ſide,
Was ready way vnto the foreſaid fields,
Where louers liue, and bloudie Martialiſts,
But either ſort containd within his bounds.
The left hand path declining fearfully,
Was ready downfall to the deepeſt hell.
Where bloudie furies ſhakes their whips of ſteele,
And poore Ixion turnes an endles wheele.
Where Vsurers are choakt with melting golde,
And wantons are imbraſte with ougly ſnakes:
And murderers grone with neuer killing wounds,
And periurde wights ſcalded in boyling lead,
And all foule ſinnes with torments ouerwhelmd,
Twixt theſe two waies, I trod the middle path,
Which brought me to the faire Elizian greene.
In midſt whereof there ſtandes a ſtately Towre,
The walles of braſſe, the gates of Adamant.
Heere finding Pluto with his Proſerpine,
I shewed my paſport humbled on my knee.
Whereat faire Proſerpine began to ſmile,
And begd that onely ſhe might giue me doome.
Pluto was pleaſd and ſealde it with a kiſſe.
Forthwith (Reuenge) she rounded thee in th’eare,
And bad thee lead me through the gates of Hor:
Where dreames haue paſſage in the ſilent night.
No ſooner had ſhe ſpoke but we were heere,
I wot not how, in twinkling of an eye.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Then know, Andrea, that thou ariu’d
Where thou ſhalt ſee the author of thy death:
Don Balthazar the Prince of Portingale
Depriu’d of life by Bel-imperia:
Heere ſit we downe to ſee the miſterie,
And ſerue for Chorus in this tragedie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Spaniſh King, Generall, Caſtille, Hieronimo, King.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now ſay L.Generall, how fares our Campe?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: All wel my ſoueraigne Liege, except ſome few,
That are deceaſt by fortune of the warre.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But what portends thy cheerefull countenance,
And poſting to our preſence this in haſt?
Speak, man, hath fortune giuen vs viƈtorie?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Viƈtorie my Liege, and that with little loſſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Our Portingals will pay vs tribute then.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Tribute and wonted homage therewithall.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then bleſt be heauen, and guider of the heauens,
From whoſe faire influence ſuch iuſtice flowes.

line.foreign: O multum dileƈte Deo, tibi militat ather,
Et coniurata curuato poplito gentes
Succumbunt: reƈtiſoror eſt viƈtoria iuris.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thanks to my louing brother of Caſtile.
But Generall, vnfolde in breefe diſcourſe,
Your forme of battell and your warres ſucceſſe,
That, adding all the pleaſure of thy newes,
Vnto the height of former happines,
With deeper wage and greater dignitie,
We may reward thy blisfull chiualrie.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Where Spaine and Portingale do ioyntly knit
Their frontiers, leaning on each others bound:
There met our armies in the proud aray,
Both furniſht well, both full of hope and feare:
Both menacing alike with daring ſhowes,
Both vaunting ſundry colours of deuice,
Both cheerly sounding trumpets, drums and fifes,
Both raiſing dreadfull clamors to the skie,
That valleis, hils, and riuers made rebound,
And heauen it ſelfe was frighted with the ſound.
Our battels both were pitcht in ſquadron forme,
Each corner ſtrongly fenſt with wings of ſhot,
But ere we ioyned and came to puſh of Pike,
I brought a ſquadron of our readieſt ſhot,
From out our rearward to begin the fight,
They brought another wing to incounter vs:
Meane while our ordinance plaid on either ſide,
And Captaines ſtroue to haue their valours tride.
Don Pedro, their chiefe horſemens Corlonell,
Did with his Cornet brauely make attempt,
To break the order of our battell rankes.
But Don Rogero, worthy man of warre,
Marcht forth againſt him with our Musketiers,
And ſtopt the mallice of his fell approch.
While they maintaine hot skirmiſh too and fro,
Both battailes ioyne and fall to handie blowes.
Their violent ſhot reſembling th’oceans rage,
When roaring lowd and with a ſwelling tide,
It beats vpon the rampiers of huge rocks,
And gapes to ſwallow neighbour bounding lands.
Now while Bellona rageth heere and there,
Thick ſtormes of bullets ran like winters haile,
And ſhiuered Launces darke the troubled aire.

line.foreign: Pede pes & cuſpide cuſpis,
Anniſonant annis vir petiturque viro.

speech.line: On euery ſide drop Captaines to the ground,
And Souldiers ſome ill maimde, some ſlaine outright:
Heere falls a body ſeindred from his head,
There legs and armes lye bleeding on the graſſe,
Mingled with weapons and vnboweled ſteeds:
That ſcattering ouer ſpread the purple plaine.
In all this turmoyle three long hovres and more,
The viƈtory to neither part inclinde,
Till Don Andrea with his braue Launciers
In their maine battell made ſo great a breach,
That halfe diſmaid, the multitude retirde:
But Balthazar the Portingales young Prince,
Brought reſcue and encouragde them to ſtay:
Heere-hence the fight was eagerly renewd,
And in that confliƈt was Andrea ſlaine.
Braue man at arms, but weake to Balthazar.
Yet while the Prince inſulting ouer him,
Breathd out proud vaunts, ſounding to our reproch,
Friendſhip and hardie valour ioyned in one,
Prickt forth Horatio our Knight Marſhals ſonne,
To challenge forth that Prince in ſingle fight:
Not long betweene theſe twain the fight indurde,
But ſtraight the Prince was beaten from his horſe,
And forcſt to yeeld him priſoner to his foe:
When he was taken, all the reſt they fled,
And our Carbines purſued them to the death,
Till Phoebus wauing to the weſtern deepe,
Our Trumpeters were chargde to ſound retreat.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thanks good L. Generall for theſe good newes,
And for some argument of more to come,
Take this and weare it for thy ſoueraignes ſake.
But tell me now, haſt thou confirmed a peace?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: No peace my Liege, but peace conditionall,
That if with homage tribute be well paid,
The fury of your forces wilbe ſtaide.
And to this peace their Viceroy hath ſubſcribde,
And made a ſolemne vow that during life,
His tribute ſhalbe truely paid to Spaine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Theſe words, theſe deeds, become thy perſon wel.
But now Knight Marhsall frolike with thy King,
For tis thy Sonne that winnes this battels prize.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Long may he liue to ſerue my ſoueraigne liege,
And ſoone decay vnleſſe he ſerue my liege.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Nor thou nor he ſhall dye without reward.
What meanes this warning of this trumpets ſound?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Thistels me that your graces men of warre,
Such as warres fortune hath reſeru’d from death,
Come marching on towards your royall ſeate,
To ſhow themſelues before your Maiestie,
For ſo I gaue in charge at my depart.
Whereby by demonſtration ſhall appeare,
That all (except three hundred or few more)
Are ſafe returnd and by their foes inricht.

scene.stagedir: The Armie enters, Balthazar betweene Lorenzo and Horatio captiue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: A gladſome ſight! I long to ſee them heere.
Was that the warlike Prince of Portingale
That by our Nephew was in triumph led?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: It was my Liege, the Prince of Portingale.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But what was he that on the other ſide,
Held him by th’arme as partner of the prize?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: That was my ſonne my gratious ſoueraigne,
Of whome, though from his tender infancie,
My louing thoughts did neuer hope but well:
He neuer pleaſd his fathers eyes till now,
Nor fild my hart with ouercloying ioyes.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe let them march once more about theſe walles,
That ſtaying them we may conferre and talke,
With our braue priſoner and his double guard.
Hieoronimo, it greatly pleaſeth vs
That in our viƈtorie thou haue a ſhare,
By vertue of thy worthy ſonnes exploit.
Bring hether the young Prince of Portingale,
The reſt martch on, but ere they be diſmiſt,
We will beſtow on euery ſouldier two duckets
And on euery leader ten, that they may know
Our largeſſe welcomes them.
Welcome Don Balthazar, welcome Nephew,
And thou Horatio thou art welcome too:
Young Prince, although thy fathers hard miſdeedes,
In keeping backe the tribute that he owes,
Deſerue but euill meaſure at our hands:
Yet ſhalt thou know that Spaine is honorable.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: The treſpaſſe that my father made in peace,
Is now controlde by fortune of the warres:
And cards once dealt, it bootes not aske why ſo,
His men are ſlaine, a weakening to his Realme,
His colours ceaz’d, a blot vnto his name,
His Sonne diſtreſt, a corſiue to his hart,
Theſe puniſhments may cleare his late oﬀence.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I Balthazar, if he obſerue this truce,
Our peace will grow the ſtronger for theſe warres:
Meane while liue thou though not in libertie,
Yet free from bearing any ſeruile yoake.
For in our hearing thy deſerts were great,
And in our ſight thy-ſelfe art gratious.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: And I ſhall ſtudie to deſerue this grace.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But tell me,—for their holding makes me doubt,
To hich of theſe twaine art thou priſoner.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: To me my Liege.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: To me my Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: This hand firſt tooke his courſer by the raines.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But firſt my launce did put him from his horſe.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I ceaz’d his weapon and enioyde it firſt.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But firſt I forc’d him lay his weapons downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let goe his arm vpon our priviledge.
Say worthy Prince, to whether didſt thou yeeld?

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: To him in curteſie, to this perforce:
He ſpake me faire, this other gaue me ſtrokes:
He promiſde life, this other threatned death:
He wan my loue, this other conquerd me;
And truth to ſay I yeeld my ſelfe to both.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: But that I knaw your grace for iuſt and wiſe,
And might ſeeme partiall in this diﬀerence,
Inforƈt by nature and by law of armes,
My tongue ſhould plead for young Horatios right.
He hunted well that was a Lyons death,
Not he that in a garment wore his skin:
So Hares may pull dead Lyons by the beard.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Content thee Marſhall thou ſhalt haue no wrong,
And for thy ſake thy Sonne ſhall want no right.
Will both abide the cenſure of my doome?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I craue no better than your grace awards.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Nor I, although I ſit beside my right.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then by iudgement thus your ſtrife shall end,
You both deſerue and both ſhall haue reward.
Nephew, thou tookſt his weapon and his horse,
His weapons and his horſe are thy reward.
Horatio, thou didſt force him firſt to yeeld,
His ranſome therefore is thy valours fee:
Appoint the ſum as you ſhall both agree.
But Nephew thou ſhalt haue the Prince in guard,
For thine eſtate beſt fitteth ſuch a guest.
Horatios houſe were ſmall for all his traine,
Yet in regard they ſubſtance paſſeth his,
And that iuſt guerdon may befall deſert,
To him we yeeld the armour of the Prince.
How likes Don Balthazar of this deuice?

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Right well my Liege, if this prouizo were,
That Don Horatio beare vs company,
Whome I admire and loue for chiualrie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Horatio, leaue him not that loues thee ſo,
Now let vs hence to ſee our ſouldiers paide,
And feaſt our priſoner as our friendly gueſt.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Is our embaſſadour diſpatcht for Spaine?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Two daies (my Liege) are paſt ſince his depart.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: And tribute paiment gone along with him?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Then reſt we heere a while in our vnreſt.
And feede our ſorrowes with ſome inward ſighes,
For deepeſt cares break neuer into teares.
But wherefore ſit I in a Regall throne,
This better ſits a wretches endles moane.
Yet this is higher then my fortuues reach,
And therefore better then my ſtate deſerues.
I, I, this earth, Image of mellancholly,
Seeks him whome fates adiudge to miſerie:
Heere let me lye, now am I at the loweſt.

line.foreign: Qui iacet in terra non habet vnde cadat,
In me conſumpſit vires fortuna nocendo,
Nil ſuperest vt iam possit obeſſe magis.

speech.line: Yes, Fortune may bereaue me of my Crowne:
Heere take it now, let Fortune doe her worſt,
She will not rob me of this ſable weed.
O no, ſhe enuies none but pleaſant things,
Such is the folly of diſpightfull chance:
Fortune is blinde and ſees not my deſerts,
So is ſhe deafe and heares not my laments:
And coulde ſhe heare, yet is ſhe willfull mad,
And therefore will not pittie my diſtreſſe.
Suppoſe that ſhe coulde pittie me, what then?
What helpe can be expeƈted at her hands?
Whoſe foote ſtanding on a rowling ſtone,
And minde more mutable then fickle windes.
Why waile I then wheres hope of no redreſſe?
O yes, complaining makes my greefe ſeeme leſſe.
My late ambition hath diſtaind my faith,
My breach of faith occaſioned bloudie warres,
Thoſe bloudie warres haue ſpent my treaſure,
And with my treaſure my peoples blood,
And with their blood, my ioy and beſt beloued,
My beſt beloued, my ſweet and onely Sonne.
O wherefore went I not to warre my ſelfe?
The cauſe was mine I might haue died for both:
My yeeres were mellow, but his young and greene,
My death were naturall, but his was forced.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: No doubt my Liege but ſtill the Prince ſuruiues.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Suruiues, I where?

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: In Spaine, a priſoner by miſchance of warre.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Then they haue ſlaine him for his fathers fault.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: That were a breach to common lawe of armes.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: They recke no lawes that meditate reuenge.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: His ranſomes worth will ſtay from foule reuenge.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: No, if he liued the newes would ſoone be heere.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Nay euill newes flie faſter ſtill than good.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Tell me no more of newes, for he is dead.

speech.speaker: Villup.
speech.line: My ſoueraign pardon the Author of ill newes,
And Ile bewray the fortune of thy Sonne.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Speake on, Ile guerdon thee, what ere it be.
Mine eare is ready to receiue ill newes,
My hart growne hard gainſt miſchiefes battery,
Stand vp I ſay and tell thy tale at large.

speech.speaker: Villup.
speech.line: Then heare that truth which theſe mine eies have ſeene.
When both the armies were in battell ioynd,
Don Balthazar amidſt the thickeſt troupes,
To winne renowme, did wondrous feats of armes:
Amongſt the reſt I ſaw him hand to hand
In ſingle fight with their Lord Generall.
Till Alexandro, that heere counterfeits,
Vnder the colour of a duteous freend,
Diſcharged his Piſtoll at the Princes back,
As though he would haue ſlaine their Generall.
But therwithall Don Balthazar fell downe:
And when he fell then we began to flie,
But, had he liued the day had ſure bene ours.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: O wicked forgerie: O traiterous miſcreant.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Hold thou thy peace, but now Villuppo ſay,
Where then became the carkaſſe of my Sonne?

speech.speaker: Villup.
speech.line: I ſaw them drag it to the Spaniſh tents.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: I, I, my nightly dreames haue tolde me this:
Thou falſe, vnkinde, vnthankfull, traiterous beaſt,
Wherein had Balthazar oﬀended thee,
That thou ſhouldſt thus betray him to our foes?
Waſt Spaniſh golde that bleared ſo thine eyes,
That thou couldſt ſee no part of our deſerts?
Perchance becauſe thou art Terſeraes Lord,
Thou hadſt ſome hope to weare this Diadome,
If firſt my Sonne and then my ſelfe were ſlaine:
But thy ambitious thought ſhall breake thy neck.
I, this was it that made thee ſpill his bloud,
speech.stagedir: Take the crowne and put it on againe.
speech.line: But Ile now weare it till thy bloud be ſpilt.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Vouchsafe( dread Soueraigne to heare me ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Away with him, his ſight is ſecond hell,
Keepe him till we determine of his death.
If Balthazar be dead, he ſhall not liue.
Villuppo follow vs for thy reward.

speech.speaker: Villup.
speech.line: Thus haue I with an enuious forged tale,
Deceiued the King, betraid mine enemy,
And hope for guerdon of my villany.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Signior Horatio, this is the place and houre,
Wherein I muſt intreat thee to relate,
The circumſtance of Don Andreas death:
Who liuing was my garlands ſweeteſt flower,
And in his death hath buried my delights.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: For loue of him and ſeruice to your ſelfe,
I nill refuſe this heauy dolefull charge.
Yet teares and ſighes, I feare will hinder me.
When both our Armies were enioynd in fight.
Your worthie chiualier admiſt the thikſt,
For glorious cauſse ſtill aiming at the faireſt,
Was at the laſt by yong Don Balthazar
Encountered hand to hand: their fight was long,
Their harts were great, their clamours menacing,
Their ſtrength alike, their ſtrokes both dangerous.
But wrathfull Nemeſis that wicked power,
Enuying at Andreas praiſe and worth,
Cut ſhort his life to end his praiſe and woorth.
She, ſhe her ſelfe diſguiſde in armours maske,
(As Pallas was before proud Pergamus:)
Brought in a freſh ſupply of Halberdiers,
Which pauncht his horſe and dingd him to the ground,
Then yong Don Balthazar, with ruthles rage,
Taking aduantage of his foes distreſſe,
Did finiſh what his Halberdiers begun,
And left not till Andreas life was done.
Then though too late incenſt with iuſt remorce,
I with my band ſet foorth againſt the Prince,
And brought him priſoner from his Halberdiers.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Would thou hadſt ſlaine him that ſo ſlew my loue.
But then was Don Andreas carkasse lost?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: No, that was it for which I cheefely ſtroue,
Nor ſtept I back till I recouerd him:
I tooke him vp and wound him in mine armes.
And welding him vnto my priuate tent,
There laid him downe and dewd him with my teares,
And ſighed and ſorrowed as became a freend.
But neither freendly ſorrow, ſighes nor teares,
Could win pale death from his vsurped right.
Yet this I did, and leſſe I could not doe:
I ſaw him honoured with due funerall,
This ſcarfe I pluckt from oﬀ his liueles arme,
And wear it in remembrance of my freend.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I know the ſcarfe, would he had kept it ſtill.
For, had he liued, he would haue kept it still,
And worne it for his Bel-imperias ſake:
For twas my fauour at his laſt depart.
But now weare thou it both for him and me,
For after him thou haſt deſerued it beſt.
But for thy kindnes in his life and death,
Be ſure while Bel-imperias life endures,
She will be Don Horatios thankfull freend.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: And (madame) Don Horatio will not ſlacke,
Humbly to ſerue faire Bel-imperia.
But now, if your good liking ſtand thereto,
Ile craue your pardon to goe ſeeke the Prince,
For ſo the Duke your father gaue me charge.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I, goe Horatio, leaue me heere alone,
For ſolitude beſt fits my cheereles mood. —
Yet what auailes to waile Andreas death,
From whence Horatio proues my ſecond loue?
Had he not loued Andrea as he did,
He could not ſit in Bel-imperias thoughts.
But how can loue finde harbour in my breſt,
Till I reuenge the death of my beloued.
Yes, ſecond loue ſhall further my reuenge.
Ile loue Horatio, my Andreas freend,
The more to ſpight the Prince that wrought his end:
And where Don Balthazar that slew my loue,
Himſelfe now pleades for fauour at my hands,
He ſhall in rigour of my iuſt diſdaine,
Reape long repentance for his murderous deed: —
For what waſt els but murderous cowardiſe,
So many to oppreſſe one valiant knight,
Without reſpeƈt of honour in the fight?
And heere he comes that murdred my delight.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Siſter, what meanes this melanchollie walke?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: That for a while I wiſh no company.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: But heere the Prince is come to viſite you.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: That argues that he liues in libertie.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: No Madame, but in pleaſing ſeruitude.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Your priſon then belike is your conceit.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I by conceit my freedome is enthralde.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Then with conceite enlarge your ſelfe againe.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: What if conceite haue laid my hart to gage?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Pay that you borrowed and recouer it.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I die if it returne from whence it lyes.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: A hartles man and liue? A miracle.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I Lady, loue can work ſuch miracles.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Tuſh, tuſh, my Lord, let goe theſe ambages,
And in plaine tearmes acquaint her with your loue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What bootes complaint, when thers no remedy?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Yes, to your gratious ſelfe muſt I complaine,
In whoſe faire anſwere lyes my remedy,
On whoſe perfeƈtion all my thoughts attend,
On whoſe aſpeƈt mine eyes finde beauties bowre,
In whoſe tranſlucent breſt my hart is lodgde.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Alas my Lord, theſe but words of courſe,
And but deuiſe to driue me from this place.

scene.stagedir: She in going in lets fall her Gloue, which

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Madame, your Gloue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Thanks good Horatio, take it for thy paines.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Signior Horatio stoopt in happie time.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I reapt more grace that I deſeru’d or hop’d.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My Lord, be not diſmaid for what is paſt,
You know that women oft are humerous:
Theſe clouds will ouerblow with little winde.
Let me alone, Ill ſcatter them my ſelfe:
Meane while let vs deuiſe to ſpend the time,
In ſome delightfull ſports and reuelling.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The King my Lords is comming hither ſtraight,
To feaſt the Portingall Embaſſadour;
Things were in readines before I came.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Then heere it fits vs to attend the King,
To welcome hither our Embaſſadour,
And learne my Father and my Countries health.

scene.stagedir: Enter the banquet, Trumpets, the King,

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: See Lord Embaſſadour, how Spaine intreats
Their priſoner Balthazar, thy Viceroyes Sonne:
We pleaſure more in kindenes than in warres.

speech.speaker: Embaſſ.
speech.line: Sad is our King, and Portingale laments,
Suppoſing that Don Balthazar is ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: So am I ſlaine by beauties tirannie. —
You ſee my Lord how Balthazar is ſlaine.
I frolike with the Duke of Caſtiles Sonne,
Wrapt euery houre in pleaſures of the Court,
And graſte with fauours of his Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Put oﬀ your greetings till our feaſt be done,
Now come and ſit with vs and taſte our cheere.
Sit downe young Prince, you are our ſecond gueſt:
Brother ſit downe, and Nephew take your place,
Signior Horatio waite thou vpon our cup,
For well thou haſt deſerued to be honored.
Now Lordings fall too, Spaine is Portugall,
And Portugall is Spaine, we both are freends,
Tribute is paid, and we enioy our right.
But where is olde Hieronimo our Marhſall,
He promiſed vs in honor of our guest,
To grace our banquet with ſome pompous ieſt.
speech.stagedir: Enter Hieronimo with a Drum, three Knights, each his Scutchin, then he fetches three Kings, they take their Crownes and them captiue.
speech.line: Hieronimo, this maske contents mine eie,
Although I ſound well not the miſterie.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: The firſt arm’d knight that hung his Scutchin vp,
speech.stagedir: He takes the Scutchin ahd giues it to the King.
speech.line: Was Engliſh Robert, Earle of Gloſester,
Who, when king Stephen bore ſway in Albion,
Arriued with fiue and twenty thouſand men,
In Portingale, and by ſucceſſe of warre,
Enforced the King then but a Saraſin,
To beare the yoake of the Engliſh Monarchie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Lord of Portingale, by this you ſ,
That which may comfort both your King and you,
And make your late diſcomfort seeme the leſſe.
But ſay Hieronimo, what was the next?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: The ſecond Knight that hung his Scutchin vp,
speech.stagedir: He doth as he did before.
speech.line: Was Edmond Earle of Kent in Albion,
When Engliſh Richard wore the Diadem,
He came likewiſe and razed Lisbon walles,
And tooke the King of Portingale in fight: —
For which, and other ſuchlike ſeruice done,
He after was created Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: This is another ſpeciall argument,
That Portingale may daine to beare our yoake,
When it by little England hath beene yoakt:
But now Hieronimo what were the laſt?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: The third and laſt not leaſt in our account,
Was as the reſt a valiant Engliſhman,
Braue Iohn of Gaunt the Duke of Lancaſter,
As by his Scutchin plainely may appeare.
He with a puiſſant armie came to Spaine,
And tooke our Kinge of Caſtile priſoner.

speech.speaker: Embass.
speech.line: This is an argument for our Viceroy,
That Spaine may not inſult for her ſucceſſe,
Since Engliſh warriours likewiſe conquered Spaine,
And made them bow their knees to Albion.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Hieronimo, I drinke to thee for this deuiſe.
Which hath pleaſde both the Embaſſador and me:
Pledge me Hieronimo, if thou loue the King.
My Lord, I feare we ſit but ouer-long.
Vnleſſe our dainties were more delicate, —
But welcome are to you the beſt we haue.
Now let vs in that you may be diſpatcht,
I think our councell is already ſet.

speech.speaker: Andrea.
speech.line: Come we for this from depth of vnder ground, —
To ſee him feaſt that gaue me my deaths wound?
These pleaſant ſights are ſorrow to my ſoule,
nothing but league, and loue and banqueting?

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Be ſtill Andrea ere we goe from hence,
Ile turne their freendſhip into fell deſpight,
Their loue to mortall hate, their day to night,
Their hope into diſpaire, their peace in warre,
Their ioyes to paine, their bliſe to miſerie.

speech.speaker: Lorenzo.
speech.line: My lord, though Bel-imperia ſeeme thus coy,
Let reaſon holde you in your wonted ioy:
In time the ſauage Bull ſuſtaines the yoake,
In time all haggard Hawkes will ſtoope to lure,
In time ſmall wedges cleaue the hardest Oake,
In time the flint is pearſt with ſofteſt ſhower,
And ſhe in time will fall from her diſdaine,
And rue the ſuﬀerance of your freendly paine.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: No, ſhe is wilder and more hard withall,
Then beaſt, or bird, or tree, or ſtony wall.
But wherefore blot I Bel-imperias name?
It is my fault, not ſhe that merits blame.
My feature is not to content her ſight,
My wodres are rude and worke her no delight.
The lines I ſend her are but harſh and ill,
Such as doe drop from Pan and Marsias quill.
My preſents are not of ſuﬀicient coſt,
And being worthles all my labours loſt.
Yet might ſhe loue me for my valiancie,
I but thats ſlaundred by captiuitie.
Yet might ſhe loue me to content her ſire:
I but her reaſon maſters his deſire.
Yet might ſhe loue me as her brothers freend,
I, but her hopes aime at ſome other end.
Yet might ſhe loue me to vpreare her ſtate,
I, but perhaps ſhe hopes ſome nobler mate.
Yet might ſhe loue me as her beauteous thrall,
I, but I feare ſhe cannot loue at all.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My Lord, for my ſake leaue theſe extaſies,
And doubt not but weele finde ſome remedie.
Some cauſe there is that lets you not be loued:
Firſt that muſt needs be knowne and then remoued.
What if my Siſter loue ſome other Knight?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: My ſommers day will turne to winters night.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I haue already founde a ſtrategeme,
To ſound the bottome of this doubtfull theame.
My Lord, for once you ſhall be rulde by me,
Hinder me not what ere you heare or ſee.
By force or faire meanes will I caſt about,
To finde the truth of all this queſtion out.
Ho Pedringano.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Signior.

line.foreign: Vien que preſto.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Hath your Lordſhip any ſeruice to command me?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I Pedringano, ſeruice of import:
And not to ſpend the time in trifling words,
Thus ſtands the caſe; it is not long thou knowſt,
Since I did ſhield thee from my fathers wrath.
For thy conueniance in Andreas loue:
For which thou wert adiudg’d to puniſhment,
I ſtood betwixt thee and thy puniſhment:
And ſince, thou knoweſt how I haue favored thee.
Now to these fauours will I adde reward,
Not with faire woords, but ſtore of golden coyne,
And lands and liuing ioynd with dignities,
If thou but ſatisfie my iust demaund.
Tell truth and haue me for thy laſting freend.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: What ere it be your Lordſhip ſhall demaund,
My bounden duety bids me tell the truth.
If caſe it lye in me to tell the truth.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Then Pedringano this is my demaund,
Whome loues my ſiſter Bel-imperia?
For ſhe repoſeth all her trust in thee:
Speak man, and gaine both freendſhip and reward,
I meane, whome loues ſhe in Andreas place?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Alas my Lord, ſince Don Andreas death,
I haue no credit with her as before,
And therefore know not if ſhe loue or no.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Nay if thou dally then I am thy foe,
And feare ſhall force what frendſhip cannot winne.
Thy death ſhall bury what thy life conceales.
Thou dyeſt for more eſteeming her than me.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Oh ſtay my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Yet ſpeak the truth and I will guerdon thee
And ſhield thee from what euer can enſue,
And will conceale what eer proceeds from thee,
But if thou dally once againe, thou dieſt.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: If madame Bel-imperia be in loue —

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: What villaine ifs and ands?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Oh ſtay my lord, ſhe loues Horatio.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: What Don Horatio our Knight Marſhals ſonne?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Euen him my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Now ſay, but how knoweſt thou he is her loue?
And thou ſhalt finde me kinde and liberall:
Stand vp I ſay, and feareles tell the truth.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: She ſent him letters which my ſelfe peruſde,
Full fraught with lines and arguments of loue,
Perferring him before Prince Balthazar.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Sweare on this croſſe that what thou ſaieſt is true,
And that thou wilt conſeale what thou haſt tolde.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I ſweare to both by him that made vs all.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: In hope thine oath is true, heeres thy reward.
But if I proue thee periurde and vniuſt,
This very ſword whereon thou tookſt thine oath,
Shall be the worker of thy tragedie.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: What I haue ſaide is true, and ſhall for me,
Be ſtill conceald from Bel-imperia.
Beſides your Honors liberalitie,
Deſerues my duteous ſeruice, euen till death.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Let this be all that thou ſhalt doe for me,
Be watchfull when, and where theſe louers meete,
And giue me notice in ſome ſecret ſort.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I will my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Then ſhalt thou finde that I am liberall,
Thou knowſt that I can more aduance thy ſtate
Then ſhe, be therefore wiſe and faile me not.
Goe and attend her as thy cuſtome is,
Leaſt abſence make her think thou dooſt amiſſe.
Why ſo: Tam armis quam ingenio:
Where wordes preuaile not, violence preuailes.
But golde doth more than either of them both.
How likes Prince Balthazar this ſtrategeme?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Both well, and ill: it makes me glad and ſad:
Glad, that I know the hinderer of my loue,
Sad, that I fear ſhe hates me whome I loue.
Glad, that I know on whome to be reueng’d;
Sad, that ſheele flie me if I take reuenge.
Yet muſt I take reuenge or dye my ſelfe,
For loue reſiſted growes impatient.
I think Horatio be my deſtinde plague,
Firſt in his hand he brandiſhed a ſword,
And with that ſword he fiercely waged warre,
And in that warre he gaue me dangerous wounds,
And by thoſe wounds he forced me to yeeld,
And by my yeelding I became his ſlaue.
Now in his mouth he carries pleaſing words,
Which pleaſing wordes doe harbour ſweet conceits,
Which ſweet conceits are lim’d with ſlie deceits,
Which ſlie deceits ſmooth Bel-imperias eares,
And through her eares diue downe into her hart,
And in her hart ſet him where I ſhould ſtand.
Thus hath he tane my body by force,
And now by ſleight would captiuate my ſoule:
But in his fall ile tempt the deſtinies,
And either looſe my life or winne my loue.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Lets goe my Lord, your ſtaying ſtaies reuenge,
Doe you hut follow me and gaine your loue,
Her fauour muſt be wonne by his remooue.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Now Madame, ſince by fauour of your loue,
Our hidden ſmoke is turnd to open flame:
And that with lookes and words we feed our though,
Two chiefe contents where more cannot be had.
Thus in the midſt of loues faire blandiſhments
Why ſhew you ſigne of inward languiſhments.

scene.stagedir: Pendringano ſheweth all to the Prince and

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: My hart Ƒſweet freend) is like a ſhip at ſea,
She wiſheth port, where riding all at eaſe,
She mad repaire what ſtormie times haue worne:
And leaning on the ſhore may ſing with ioy,
That pleaſure followes paine, and bliſſe annoy.
Poſſeſsion of thy loue is th’onely port,
Wherein my hart with feares and hopes long toſt,
Each howre doth wiſh and long to make reſort,
There to repaire the ioyes that it hath loſt:
And ſitting ſafe to ſing in Cupids quire,
That ſweeteſt bliſſe is crowne of loues deſire.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: O ſleepe mine eyes, ſee not my loue prophande,
Be deafe my ears, heare not my diſcontent,
Dye hart, another ioyes what thou deſerueſt.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Watch ſtill mine eyes, to ſee this loue disioyned,
Heare ſtill mine eares, to heare them both lament,
Liue hart to ioy at fond Horatios fall.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Why ſtands Horatio ſpeecheles all this while?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The leſſe I ſpeak, the more I meditate.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: But whereon dooſt thou cheifely meditate?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: On dangers paſt, and pleaſures to enſue.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: On pleaſures past, and dangers to ensue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What dangers, and what pleſures dooſt thou mean?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Dangers of warre, and pleaſures of our loue.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Dangers of death, but pleaſures none at all.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Let dangers goe, thy warre ſhall be with me,
But ſuch a warring as breakes no bond of peace.
Speake thou faire words, ile croſſe them with faire words,
Send thou ſweet looks, ile meet them with ſweet looks,
Write louing lines, ile anſwere louing lines,
Giue me a kiſſe, ile counterchecke thy kiſſe,
Be this our warring peace, or peacefull warre.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But gratious Madame, then appoint the field,
Where triall of this warre ſhall first be made.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Ambitious villaine, how his boldenes growes?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Then be thy fathers pleaſant bower in the field,
Where firſt we vowd a mutuall amitie:
The Court were dangerous, that place is ſafe:
Our howre ſhalbe when Vesper ginnes to riſe,
That ſummons home diſtresfull trauellers.
There none ſhall heare vs but the harmeles birds,
Happelie the gentle Nightingale,
Shall carroll vs a ſleepe ere we be ware.
And ſinging wit the prickle at her breaſt,
Tell our delight and mirthfull dalliance.
Till then each houre will ſeeme a yeere and more.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But honie ſweet, and honorable loue,
Returne we now into your fathers ſight.
Dangerous ſuſpition waits on our delight.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I, danger mixt with iealous deſpite,
Shall ſend thy ſoule into eternalle night.

scene.stagedir: Enter King of Spaine, Portingale Embaſſadour, Don Ciprian, &c.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brother of Caſtile, to the Princes loue:
What ſaies your daughter Bel-imperia?

speech.speaker: Cip.
speech.line: Although ſhe coy it as becomes her kinde,
And yet diſſemble that she loues the Prince:
I doubt not I, but ſhe will ſtoope in time.
And were ſhe froward, which ſhe will not be,
Yet hŒerin ſhall ſhe follow my aduice,
Which is to loue him or forgoe my loue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then Lord Embaſſadour of Portingale,
Aduiſe thy King to make this marriage vp,
For ſtrengthening of our late-confirmed league,
I know no better meanes to make vs freends.
Her dowry ſhall be large and liberall,
Beſides that, ſhe is daughter and halfe heire,
Vnto our brother heere Don Ciprian,
And ſhall enioy the moitie of his land,
Ile grace her marriage with an vnckles gift,
And this it is, in caſe the match goe forward,
The tribute which you pay ſhalbe releaſt,
And if by Balthazar she haue a Sonne,
He ſhall enioy the kingdome after vs.

speech.speaker: Embaſ.
speech.line: Ile make the motion to my ſoueraigne Liege,
And worke it if my counſaile may preuaile.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Doe ſo my Lord, and if he giue conſent,
I hope his preſence heere will honour vs
In celebration of the nuptiall day,
And let himſelfe determine of the time.

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your grace command me ought beſid?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Commend me to the King, and so farewell.
But wheres Prince Balthazar to take his leaue?

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: That is perfourmd alreadie my good Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Amongſt the reſt of what you haue in charge,
The Princes raunſome muſt not be forgot:
Thats none of mine, but his that tooke him priſoner,
And well his forwardnes deſerues reward.
It was Horatio our Knight Marſhals ſonne.

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Betweene vs theres a price already pitcht,
And ſhall be sſent with all conuenient ſpeed.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then once againe farewell my Lord.

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Farwell my lord of Caſtile and the reſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now brother, you muſt make ſome little paines,
To winne faire Bel-imperia from her will:
Young Virgins must be ruled by their freends,
The Prince is amiable and loues her well,
If she negleƈt him and forgoe his loue,
She both will wrong her owne eﬆate and ours:
Therefore whiles I doe entertaine the Prince,
With greateſt pleaſure that our Court aﬀoords,
Endeauor you to winne your daughters thoughts,
If ſhe giue back, all this will come to naught.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Now that the night begins with ſable wings
To ouer-cloud the brightnes of the Sunne,
And that in darkenes pleaſures may be done:
Come Bel-imperia let vs to the bower,
And there in ſafetie passe a pleaſant hower.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I follow thee my loue, and will not backe,
Although my fainting hart controles my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Why, make you doubt of Pedringanos faith?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No he is as truſtie as my ſecond ſelfe.
Goe Pedringano watch without the gate,
And let vs known if any make approch.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: In ſteed of watching ile deſerue more golde,
By fetching Don Lorenzo to this match.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: What means my loue?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I know not what my ſelfe:
And yet my hart foretels me ſome some miſchaunce.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Sweet ſay not ſo, faire fortune is our freend,
And heauens haue ſhut vp day to pleasure vs.
The ſtarres thou ſeest holde back their twinckling ſhine,
And Luna hides her ſelfe to pleasure vs.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Thou haſt preuailed, ile conquer my miſdoubt,
And in thy loue and councell drowne my feare:
I feare no more, loue now is all my thoughts,
Why ſit we nat, for pleaſure asketh eaſe?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The more thou ſitſt within theſe leauy bowers,
The more will Flora decke it with her flowers.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I but if Flora ſpye Horatio heere,
Her iealous eye will think I ſit too neere.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Harke Madame how the birds record by night,
For ioy that Bel-imperia ſits in ſight.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No Cupid counterfeits the Nightingale,
To frame ſweet muſick to Horatios tale.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: If Cupid ſing, then Venus is not farre, —
I thou art Venus or ſome fairer ſtarre.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: If I be Venus thou muſt needs be Mars,
And where Mars raigneth, there muſt needs be warre.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Then thus begin our wars put forth thy hand,
That it may combat with my ruder hand.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Set forth thy foot to try the puſh of mine.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But firſt my lookes ſhall combat againſt thine.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Then ward thy ſelfe, I dart this kiſſe as thee.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Thus I retort the dart thou threwſt at me.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Nay then to gaine the glory of the field,
My twining armes ſhall yoake and make thee yeeld.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Nay then my armes are large and ſtrong with
Thus Elmes by vines are compaſt till they fall.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: O let me goe, for in my troubled eyes,
Now maiſt thou read that life in paſsion dies.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: O ſtay a while, and I will dye with thee,
So ſhalt thou yeeld, and yet haue conquerd me.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Whoſe there Pedringano? we are betraide.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lorenzo, Balthazar, Cerberin, Pedringano, diſguiſed.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My Lord away with her, take her aſide,
O ſir forbeare, your valour is already tride.
Quickly diſpatch my maiſters.
speech.stagedir: Thy hang him in the Arbor.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: What will you murder me?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I thus, and thus, theſe are the fruits of loue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: O ſaue his life and let me dye for him,
O ſaue him brother, ſaue him Balthazar:
I loued Horatio but he loued not me.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: But Balthazar loues Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Although his life were ſtill ambitious proud,
Yet is heat the higheſt now he is dead.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Murder, murder, helpe Hieronimo helpe.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Come ſtop her mouth away with her.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What outcried pluck me from my naked bed,
And chill my throbbing hart with trembling feare,
Which neuer danger yet could daunt before.
Who cals Hieronimo? ſpeak, heare I am:
I did not ſlumber, therefore twas no dreame,
No, no, it was ſome woman cride for helpe,
And heere within this garden did ſhe crie.
And in this garden muſt I reſcue her:
But ſtay! what murdrous ſpeƈtacle is this?
A man hanged vp and all the murderers gone,
And in my bower to lay the guilt on me:
This place was made for pleaſure not for death.
Thoſe garments that he weares I oft haue ſeene,
Alas it is Horatio my ſweet ſonne.
O no, but he that whilome was my ſonne,
O was it thou that call’dst me from my bed,
O ſpeak if any ſparke of life remaine.
I am thy father, who hath ſlaine my ſonne?
What ſauadge monster. not of humane kinde,
Hath heere beene glutted with thy harmeles blood,
And left thy bloudie corpes diſhonoured heere,
For me amidst this darke and dreadfull ſhades,
To drowne thee with an ocean of my teares.
O heauens, why made you night to couer ſinne?
By day this deed of darknes had not beene.
O earth why didſt thou not in time deuoure,
The vilde prophaner of this ſacred bower.
O poore Horatio, what hadſt thou miſdoone?
To leeſe thy life ere life was new begun.
O wicked butcher what ſo ere thou wert,
How could thou ſtrangle vertue and deſert?
Ay me moſt wretched that haue loſt my ioy,
In leeſing my Horatio my sweet boy.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: My husbands abſence makes my hart to throb,
Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Heere Iſabella, helpe me to lament,
For ſighes are ſtopt, and all my teares are ſpent.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: What worlde of griefe, my ſonne Horatio?
O wheres the author of this endles woe.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: To know the author were ſome eaſe of greeſe,
For in reuenge my hart would finde releefe.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: Then is he gone? and is my ſonne gone too?
O guſh out teares, fountains and flouds of teares,
Blow ſighes and raiſe and euerlaſting ſtorme.
For outrage fits our curſed wretchedness.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Sweet louely Roſe, ill pluckt before thy time,
Faire worthy ſonne, not conquerd but betraid:
Ile kiſſe thee now, for words with teares are ſtainde.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: And ile cloſe vp the glasses of his ſight,
For once theſe eyes were onely my delight,

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Seeſt thou this handkercher beſmerd with blood,
It ſhall not from me till I take reuenge:
Seest thou those wounds that yet are bleeding fresh?
Ile not intombe them till I haue reueng’d:
Then will I ioy amidst my diſcontent,
Till then my ſorrow neuer ſhalbe spent.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: The heauens are iuſt, murder cannot be hid,
Time is the author of both truth and right.
And time will bring this trecherie to light.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Meane while good Iſabella ceaſe thy plaints,
Or at the leaſt dissemble them awhile,
So ſhall we ſooner finde the praƈtise out,
And learne by whome all this was brought about.
Come Iſabell now let vs take him vp,
And beare him in from out this curſed place.
Ile ſay his dirge, ſinging fits not this caſe.

line.emph: O aliquis mihi quas pulchrum ver educet herbas

speech.stagedir: Hieroſets his breſt vnto his ſword.

line.foreign: Miſceat &noſtro detur, medicina dolori:
Aut ſiqui faciunt annum obliuia ſuccos,
Prebeat, ipſe metam megnum quicunque per orbem,
Gramina Sol pulchras eſſecit luminis oras.
Ipſe bibam quicquid meditatur ſaga veneri,
Quicquid & irranienecaca nenia neƈtit.
Omnia perpetiar, lethum quoque dums ſemelomnis,
Noſter in extinƈto moriatur peƈtora ſenſus:
Ergo tuos occulos nunquam( mea vita )vi debo.
Et tua perpetuus ſepeliuis lumina ſomnus:
Emoriar tecum Sic, ſic iuuat ire ſub vmbras.
Attamen abſiſtam properato cedere letho,
Ne mortem vindiƈta tuam tam nulla ſequatur.

scene.stagedir: Heere he throwes it from him and beares the body away.

speech.speaker: Andrea.
speech.line: Broughtſt thou me hether to increaſe my paine?
I lookt that Balthazar ſhould haue been ſlaine,
But tis my freend Horatio that is slaine,
And they abuſe faire Bel-imperia.
On whom I doted more then all the world,
Becauſe ſhe lou’d me more then all the world.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Thou talkeſt of haruest, when the corne is greene,
The end is crowne of euery worke well done:
The Sickle comes not till the corne be ripe.
Be ſtill, and ere I lead thee from this place,
Ile ſhew thee Balthazar in heauy caſe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Viceroy of Portingale, Nobles, Alexandro, Villuppo.

speech.speaker: Viceroy.
speech.line: Infortunate condition of Kings,
Seated amidſt so many helpeles doubts:
Firſt we are plaſt vpon extreameſt height,
And oft ſupplanted with exceeding heat,
But euer ſubieƈt to the wheele of chance?
And at our higheſt neuer ioy we ſo,
As we doubt and dread our ouerthrow.
So ſtriueth not the waues with ſundry winds,
As fortune toyleth in the aﬀaires of kings,
That would be feard, yet feare to be beloued,
Sith feare or loue to Kings is flatterie:
For instance Lordings, look vpon your King,
By hate depriued of his deareſt ſonne,
The only hope of our ſucceſsiue line.

speech.speaker: Nob.
speech.line: I had not thought that Alexandros hart,
Had beene enuenomde with ſuch extreame hate:
But now I ſee that words haue ſeuerall workes,
And theres no credit in the countenance.

speech.speaker: Vil.
speech.line: No, for my Lord had you beholde the traine,
That fained loue had coloured in his lookes,
When he in campe conſorted Balthazar:
Farre more inconſtant had you thought the Sunne,
That howerly coaſts the center of the earth,
Then Alexandros purpoſe to the Prince.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: No more Villuppo, thou haſt ſaid enough,
And with thy words thou ſlaieſt our wounded thoughts.
Nor ſhall I longer dally with the world:
Procraſtinating Alexandros death:
Goe ſome of you and fetch the traitor forth,
That as he is condemned he may dye.

scene.stagedir: Enter Alexandro with a Noble man and Halberts.

speech.speaker: Nob.
speech.line: In ſuch extreames, will nought but patience ſerue.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: But in extreames, what patience ſhall I vse?
Nor diſcontents it me to leaue the world,
With whome there nothing can preuaile but wrong.

speech.speaker: Nob.
speech.line: Yet hope the beſt.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Tis Heauen is my hope.
As for the earth it is too much infeƈt,
To yeeld me hope of any of her mould.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Why linger ye? bring froth that daring feend,
And let him die for his accurſed deed.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Not that I feare the extremitie of death,
For Nobles cannot ſtoop to ſeruile feare.
Doo I ( O king ) thus diſcontented liue.
But this, O this torments my labouring ſoule,
That thus I die ſuſpeƈted of a ſinne,
Whereof, as heauens haue knowne my ſecret thoughts,
So am I free from this ſuggeſtion.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: No more I ſay, to the tortures, when?
Binde him, and burne his body in thoſe flames,
speech.stagedir: They binde him to the ſtake.
speech.line: That ſhall prefigure thoſe vnquenched fiers
Of Phlegiton prepared for his ſoule.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: My guiltles death will be aueng’d on thee,
On thee Villuppo that hath maliſde thus,
Or for thy meed, haſt falſely me accnſde.

speech.speaker: Vil.
speech.line: Nay Alexandro if thou menace me,
Ile lend a hand to send thee to the lake,
Where thoſe thy words ſhall periſh with thy workes,
Iniurious traitour, monſtrous homicide.
Stay hold a while, and heer with pardon of his Maieſtie,
Lay hands vpon Villuppo.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Embaſſadour, what newes nath vrg’d this ſodain entrance?

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Know ſoueraigne L. that Balthazar doth liue.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: What ſaieſt thou? liueth Balthazar our ſonne?

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Your highnes ſonne, L. Balthazar doth liue.
And well intreated in the Court of Spaine:
Humbly commends him to your Maieſtie.
Theſe eies beheld, and theſe my followers,
With theſe the letters of the Kings commends.
Are happie witneſes of his highnes health.
speech.stagedir: The King lookes on the letters, and proceeds.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: “Thy ſonne doth liue, your tribute is receiu’d,
Thy peace is made, and we are ſatisfied:
The rest reſolue vpon as things propoſde,
For both our honors and thy benefite.”

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Theſare his highnes farther articles.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Accursed wrech to intimate theſe ills,
Againſt the life and reputation
Of noble Alexandro, come my Lord vnbinde him.
Let him vnbinde thee that is bounde to death,
To make a quitall for thy diſcontent.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Dread Lord, in kindnes you could do no leſſe,
Vpon report of ſuch a damned faƈt:
But thus we ſee our innocence hath ſau’d,
The hopeles life which thou Villuppo ſought,
By thy ſuggeſtions to haue maſſacred.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Say falſe Villuppo? wherefore didſt thou thus
Falſly betray Lord Alexandros life?
Him whom thou knoweſt, that no vnkindenes els,
But euen the ſlaughter of our deereſt ſonne,
Could once haue moued vs to haue miſconceaued.

speech.speaker: Alex.
speech.line: Say trecherous Villuppo, tell the King,
Or wherein hath Alexandro vsed thee ill?

speech.speaker: VIl.
speech.line: Rent with remembrance of ſo foule a deed,
My guiltie ſoule ſubmits me to thy doome:
For not for Alexandros iniuries,
But, for reward, and hope to be preferd:
Thus haue I ſhameleſly hazarded his life,

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: which villaine ſhalbe ranſomed with thy deeth,
And not ſo meane a torment as we heere
Deuiſed for him, who thou ſaidſt ſlew our ſonne:
But with the bittereſt torments and extreames,
That may be yet inuented for thine end:
Intreat me not, goe take the traitor hence.
And Alexandro let vs honor thee,
With publique notice of thy loyaltie,
To end thoſe things articulated heere,
By our great L. the mightie king of Spaine.
We with our councell will deliberate.
Come Alexandro keepe vs company.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Oh eies, no eies but fountains fraught with teares,
Oh life, no life, but liuely fourme of death:
Oh world, no world but maſſe of publique wrongs.
Confuſde and filde, with murder and misdeeds
Oh ſacred heauens, if this vnhallowed deed,
If this inhumane and barberous attempt,
If this incompaeable murder thus,
Of mine, but now no more my ſonne,
Shall pass vnreueald and vnreuenged paſſe,
How ſhould we tearme your dealings to be iuſt,
If you vniuſtly deale with thoſe, that in your iuſtice truſt.
The night ſad ſecretary to my mones,
With direfull viſions wake my vexed ſoule,
And with the wounds of my diſtreſfull ſonne,
Solicite me for notice of his death.
The ougly feends do ſally forth of hell,
And frame my ſteps to vnfrequented paths,
And feare my hart with fierce inflamed thoughts.
The cloudie day my diſcontents records,
Early begins to regeſter my dreames,
And driue me forth to ſeeke the murtherer.
Eies, life, world, heauens, hel, night and day,
See, ſearch, ſhew, ſend, ſome man,
Some meane, that may:
Whats heere? a letter, tuſh, it is not ſo,
A letter written to Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: For want of incke receiue this bloudie writ,
Me hath my haples brother hid from thee,
Reuenge thy ſelfe on Balthazar and him,
For these were they that murdered thy Sonne.
Hieronimo, reuenge Horatios death,
And better fare then Bel-imperia doth.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What meanes this vnexpeƈted miracle?
My Sonne ſlaine by Lorenzo and the Prince.
What cauſe had they Horatio to maligne?
Or what might mooue thee Bel-imperia,
To accuſe thy brother, had he beene the meane?
Hieronimo beware, thou art betraide,
And to intrap they life this traine is laide.
Aduiſe thee therefore, be not credulous:
This is deuiſed to endanger thee,
That thou by this Lorenzo ſhouldſt accuſe,
And he for thy diſhonour done, ſhould draw
Thy life in queſtion; and thy name in hate.
Deare was the life of my beloved Sonne,
And of his death behoues me be reueng’d:
Then hazard not thine own Hieronimo,
But liue t’eﬀeƈt thy reſolution.
I therefore will by circumſtances trie,
What I can gather to confirme this writ,
And harkning neere the Duke of Caſtiles houſe,
Cloſe if I can with Belimperia,
To liſten more, but nothing to bewray.
Now Pedringano.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Now Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Wheres thy Lady?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I know not, heers my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: How now, whoſe this, Hieronimo?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: He asketh for my Lady Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: What to doo Hieronimo? The Duke my father hath
Vpon ſome diſgrace a while remoou𔃏d her hence,
But if it be ought I may enforme her of,
Tell me Hieronimo, and ile let her know it.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Nay, nay my Lord, I thank you, it ſhall not need,
I had a ſute vnto her, but too late,
And her diſgrace makes me vnfortunate.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why ſo Hieronimo? vſe me.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Oh no my Lord, I dare not, it muſt not be.
I humbly thank your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why then farewell.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: My griefe no hart, my thoughts no tung can tell.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Come hither Pedringano, ſeeſt thou this?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: My Lord, I ſee it, and ſuſpeƈt it too.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: This is that damned villain Serberine,
That hath I feare reuealde Horatios death.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: My Lord, he could not, twas ſo lately done,
And ſince he hath not left my company.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Admit he haue not, his conditions ſuch,
As feare or flattering words may make him falſe.
I know his humour, and there with repent
That ere I vsde him in this enterpriſe.
But Pedringano, to preuent the worſt,
And cauſe I know thee ſecret as my ſoule,
Heere for thy further ſatiſfaƈtion take thou this.
And harken to me, thus it is deuiſde:
This night thou muſt, and prithee so reſolue,
Meet Serberine at S. Liugis Parke,
Thou knoweſt tis heere hard by behinde the houſe,
There take thy ſtand, and see thou ſtrike him ſure,
For dye he muſt, if we do meane to liue.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: But how ſhall Serberine be there my Lord?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Let me alone, ile ſend him to meet
The Prince and me, where thou muſt doe this deed.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: It ſhalbe done my L. it ſhall be done,
And ile goe arme my ſelfe to meet him there.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: When things ſhall alter, as I hope they wil,
Then ſhalt thou mount for this, thou knoweſt my minde.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Goe ſirra to Serberine, and bid him forthwith,
Meet the Prince and me at S. Liugis Parke,
Behinde the houſe, this euening boy.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: I goe my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: But Page.irra, let the houre be eight a clocke.
Bid him not faile.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: I flye my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Now to confirme the complot thou haſt caſt,
Of all theſe praƈtices, Ile ſpread the watch,
Vpon preciſe commandement from the king,
Strongly to guard the place where Pedringano
This night ſhall murder haples Serberine.
Thus muſt we worke that will auoide diſtruſt,
Thus must we praƈtice to preuent miſhap,
And thus one ill, another muſt expulſe.
This ſlie enquiry of Hieronimo
For Bel-imperia, breeds ſuſpition,
And this ſuſpition boads a further ill.
As for my ſelfe, I know my ſecret fault,
And ſo doe they, but I haue dealt for them.
They that for coine their ſoules endangered
To ſaue my life, for coyne ſhall venture theirs:
And better its that baſe companions dye,
Then by their life to hazard our good haps.
Nor ſhall they liue for me, to feare their faith;
Ile truſt my ſelfe, my ſelfe ſhall be my freend,
For dye they ſhall, ſlaues are ordeind to no other end.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Now Pedringano bid thy piſtoll holde,
And holde on Fortune, once more fauour me,
Giue but ſucceſe to mine attempting ſpirit,
And let me ſhift for taking of mine aime.
Heere is the golde, this is the golde propoſde,
It is no dreame that I aduenture for,
But Pedringano is possest thereof.
And he that would not ſtraine his conſcience
For him that thus his liberall purſe hath ſtretcht,
Vnworthy ſuch a fauour may he faile,
And wiſhing, want when ſuch as I preuaile.
As for the feare of apprehenſion,
I know, if need ſhould be, my noble Lord
Will ſtand betweene me and enſuing harmes.
Beſides, this place is free from all ſuſpeƈt:
Heere therefore will I ſtay and take my ſtand.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: I wonder much to what intent it is,
That we are thus expreſly chargd to watch?
Tisby commandement in the Kings own name.
But we were neuer wont to watch and ward,
So neere the Duke his brothers houſe before.
Content your ſelfe, ſtand close, theres ſomewhat int.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Heere Serberine attend and ſtay thy pace,
For heere did Don Lorenzos Page appoint,
That thou by his command ſhouldſt meet with him.
How fit a place if one were ſo diſpoſde,
Me thinks this corner is to cloſe with one.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Heere comes the bird that I must ceaze vpon,
Now Pedringano or neuer play the man.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I wonder that his Lordſhip ſtaies ſo long,
Or wherefore ſhould he ſend for me ſo late?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: For this Serberine, and thou shalt ha’te.
So there he lyes, my promiſe is performde.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: Harke Gentlemen, this is a Piſtol ſhot.
And heeres one ſlaine, ſtay the murderer.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Now by the ſorrowes of the ſoules in hell,
Who firſt laies hands on me, ile be his Prieſt.
Sirra, confeſſe, and therein play the Prieſt,
Why haſt thou thus vnkindely kild the man?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Why, becauſe he walkt abroad so late.
Come ſir, you had bene better kept your bed
Then haue committed this miſdeed ſo late.
Come to the Marſhals with the murderer.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: On to Hieronimos, helpe me heere,
To bring the murdred body with vs too.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Hieronimo, carry me before whom you will,
What ere he be ile anſwere him and you,
And doe your worſt, for I defie you all.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: How now my Lord, what makes you riſe ſo ſoone?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Feare of preuenting our miſhaps too late.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: What miſchiefe is it that we not miſtruſt?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Our greateſt ils, we leaſt mistruſt my Lord,
And in unexpeƈted harmes do hurt vs most.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Why tell me Don Lorenzo, tell me man,
If ought concernes our honor and your owne?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Nor you nor me my Lord, but both in one.
But I ſuſpeƈt, and the preſumptions great,
That by thoſe baſe confederates in our fault,
Touching the death of Don Horatio:
We are betraide to olde Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Betraide Lorenzo, tuſh it cannot be.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: A guiltie conſcience vrged with the thought,
Oﬀormer euils, eaſily cannot erre:
I am perſwaded, and diſwade me not,
That als reuealed to Hieronimo.
And therefore know that I haue cast it thus:
But heeres the Page, how now, what newes with thee?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: My lord, Serberineis ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Who? Serberine my man.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Your Highnes man my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Speak Page, who murdered him?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: He that is apprehended for the faƈt.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Who?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Pedringano.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Is Serberineſlaine that lou’d his Lord ſo well?
Iniurious villaine, murderer of his freend.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Hath Pedringano murdered Serberine?
My Lord, let me entreat you to take the paines,
To exaſperate and haſten his reuenge.
With your complaints vnto my L. the King.
This their diſſention breeds a greater doubt.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Aſſure thee Don Lorenzo he shall dye,
Or els his Highnes hardly ſhall deny.
Meane while, ile haſte the Marſhall Seſsions,
For die he ſhall for this damned deed.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why ſo, this fits our former pollicie,
And thus experience bids the wiſe to deale.
I lay the plot, he proſecutes the point,
I ſet the trap, he breakes the worthles twigs,
And ſees not that wherewith the bird was limde.
Thus hopefull men that meane to holde their owne,
Muſt look like fowlers to their deareſt freends.
He runnes to kill whome I haue holpe to catch,
And no man knowes it was my reaching fatch.
Tis hard to trust vnto a multitude,
Or any one in mine opinion,
When men themſelues their ſecrets will reueale.

scene.stagedir: Enter a meſſenger with a letter.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Boy.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Whats he?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: I haue a letter to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: From whence?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: From Pedringano that's impriſoned.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: So, he is in priſon then?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: What would he with vs?
He writes vs heere to ſtand good L. and help him in diſtres.
Tell him I haue his letters, know his minde,
And what we may let him aſſure him of.
Fellow, be gone: my boy ſhall follow thee.
This works like waxe, yet once more try thy wits,
Boy, goe conuay this purſe to Pedringano,
Thou knoweſt the priſon, cloſely giue it him:
And be aduiſde that none here there about.
Bid him be merry ſtill, but ſecret:
And though the Marſhall Seſsions be to day,
Bid him not doubt of his deliuerie.
Tell him his pardon is already ſignde,
And thereon bid him boldely be reſolued:
For, were he ready to be turned oﬀ, —
As tis my will the vttermost be tride, —
Thou with his pardon ſhalt attend him ſtill,
Shew him this boxe, tell him his pardons int,
But opent not, and if thou loueſt thy life:
But let him wiſely keepe his hopes vnknowne.
He shall not want while Don Lorenzo liues: away.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: I goe my Lord, I runne.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: But ſirra, ſee that this be cleanely done.
Now ſtands our fortune on a tickle point,
And now or neuer ends Lorenzos doubts.
One only thing is vneﬀeƈted yet,
And thats to ſee the Executioner,
But to what end? I liſt not truſt the Aire
With vtterance of our pretence therein.
For feare the priuie whiſpring of the winde
Conuay our words amongſt vnfreendly eares,
That lye too open to aduantages.

line.emph: Et quel che voglio Io neſun lo ſa,
I ntendo io quel mi baſſara.

speech.line: My Maiſter hath forbidden me to look in this box, and by my troth tis likely, if he had not warned me, I ſhould not haue had ſo much idle time: for wee mens-kinde in our mi- noritie, are like women in their vncertaintie, that they are moſt forbidden, they wil ſooneſt attempt: ſo I now. By my bare honeſty, heeres nothing but the bare emptie box: were it not ſin againſt ſecrecie, I would ſay it were a peece of gen- tlemanlike knauery. I muſt goe to Pedringano, and tell him his pardon is in this boxe, nay, I would haue ſworne it, had I not ſeene the contrary. I cannot chooſe but ſmile to thinke, how the villain wil flout the gallowes, ſcorne the audience, and deſcant on the hangman, and al preſuming of his pardon from hence. Wilt not be an odde ieſt, for me to ſtand and grace euery ieſt he makes, pointing my figner at this boxe: as who would ſay, mock on, heers thy warrant. Iſt not a ſcur- uie ieſt, that a man ſhould ieſt himſelfe to death. Alas poore Pedringano. I am in a ſorte ſorie for thee but if I ſhould be hanged with thee, I cannot weep.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Thus muſt we toyle in others mens extreames,
That know not how to rememdie our owne,
And doe them iuſtice, when vniuſtly we:
For all our wrongs can compaſſe no redreſſe.
But ſhall I neuer liue to see the day,
That I may come (by iustice to the heauens)
To know the cauſe that may my cares allay?
This toyles my body, this conſumeth age,
That onely I to all men iuſt muſt be,
And neither Gods nor men be iuſt to me.

speech.speaker: Dep.
speech.line: Worthy Hieronimo, your oﬀice askes
A care to puniſh ſuch as doe tranſgreſſe.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: So iſt my duety to regarde his death,
Who when he liued deſerued my deareſt blood:
But come, for that we came for lets begin,
For heere lyes that which bids me to be gone.
speech.stagedir: Enter Oﬀicers, Boy and Pedringano with a letter

speech.speaker: Depu.
speech.line: Bring forth the Priſoner for the Court is ſet.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Gramercy boy! but it was time to come,
For I had written to my Lord anew,
A neerer matter that concerneth him,
For feare his Lordſhip had forgotten me:
But ſith he hath rememberd me ſo well,
Come, come, come on, when ſhall we to this geere.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Stand forth thou monſter, murderer of men,
And heere for ſatisfaƈtion of the world,
Confeſſe thy folly and repent thy fault,
For ther’s thy place of execution.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: This is short worke, well, to your Marſhallſhip
Firſt I confeſſe, nor feare I death therfore,
I am the man, twas I ſlew Serberine.
But ſir, then you think this ſhalbe the place,
Where we ſhall ſatisfie you for this geare?

speech.speaker: Depu.
speech.line: I Pedrigano.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Now I think not ſo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Peace impudent, for thou ſhalt finde it ſo.
For blood with blood, ſhall while I ſit as iudge,
Be ſatisfied, and the law diſchargde.
And though my ſelfe cannot receiue the like,
Yet will I ſee that others haue their right.
Diſpatch, the faults approued and confeſt,
Hnd by our law he is condemned to die.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Come on ſir, are you ready?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: To doo what, my fine oﬀicious knaue?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: To goe to this geere.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: O ſir, you are to forward, thou wouldſt faine furniſh
me with a halter, to diſfurniſh me of my habit.
So I ſhould goe out of this geere my raiment, into that geere
the rope.
But Hangman, now I ſpy your knauery, ile not change with-
out boot, thats flat.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Come, sir.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: So then I muſt vp?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: No remedie.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Yes, but there ſhalbe for my comming downe.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Indeed heers a remedie for that.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: How?be turnd oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I truely, come are you ready.
I pray ſir diſpatch, the day goesaway.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: What doe you hang by the howre, if you doo, I may
chance to break your olde cuſtome.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Faith you haue no reaſon, for I am like to break your
yong neck.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Doſt thou mock me hangman, pray God I be not
preſerued to break your knaues pate for this.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Alas ſir, you are a foot too low to reach it, and I
hope you will neuer grow ſo high while I am in the
oﬀice.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Sirra, doſt ſee yonder boy with the box in his hand?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: What, he that points to it with his finger.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I that companion.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I know him not, but what of him?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Dooſt thou think to liue till his olde doublet will
make thee a new truſſe?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I, and many a faire yeere after, to truſſe vp many
an honeſter man then either thou or he.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: What hath he in his boxe as thou thinkſt?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Faith I cannot tell, nor I care not greatly.
Me thinks you ſhould rather hearken to your ſoules health.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Why ſirra Hangman? I take it, that that is good for
the body, is likewiſe good for the ſoule: and it may
be, in that box is balme for both.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: Wel, thou art euen the merieſt peece of mans fleſh
that ere gronde at my oﬀice doore.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Is your roaguery become an oﬀice with a knaues
name?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I, and that ſhall all they witnes that ſee you ſeale it
with a theeues name.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I prethee requeſt this good company to pray with
me.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I mary ſir, this is a good motion: my maiſters, you
see heers a good fellow.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Nay, nay, now I remember me, let them alone till
ſome other time, for now I haue no great need.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: I haue not ſeen a wretch ſo impudent.
O monſtrous times where murders are ſo light,
And where the ſoule that ſhould be ſhrinde in heauen,
Solelie delights in interdiƈted things,
Still wandring in the thornie paſſages
That intercepts it ſelfe of hapines.
Murder, O bloudy monſter, God forbid,
A fault ſo foule ſhould ſcape vnpuniſhed.
Diſpatch and ſee this execution done,
This makes me to remember thee my ſonne.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Nay ſoft, no hast.

speech.speaker: Depu.
speech.line: Why, wherefore ſtay you, haue you hope of life?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Why I.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: As how?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Why Raſcall by my pardon from the King.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: ſtand you on that, then you ſhall oﬀ with this.

speech.speaker: Depu.
speech.line: So Executioner, conuay him hence,
But let his body be vnburied.
Let not the earth be choked or infeƈt.
What that which heauens contemnes and men negleƈt.
Where ſhall I run to breath abroad my woes,
My woes whoſe weight hath wearied the earth?
Or mine exclaimes that haue ſurcharged the aire,
With ceaſles plaints, for my deceased ſonne?
The bluſtring winds conſpiring with my words,
At my lament haue moued to leaueless trees.
Diſroabde the medowes of their flowred greene,
Made mountains marſh with ſpring tides of my teares,
And broken through the brazen gates of hell,
Yet ſtill tormented is my tortured ſoule,
With broken ſighes and reſtles paſsions,
That winged mount, and houering in the aire,
Beat at the windowes of the brighteſt heauens,
Soliciting for iuſtice and reuenge:
But they are plac’t in thoſe imperiall heights,
Where countermurde with walles of diamond,
I finde the place impregnable, and they
Reſiſt my woes and giue my words no way.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: O Lord ſir, God bleſſe you ſir, the man ſir Petergade
Sir, he that was Petergade, o full of merie conceits.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Wel, what of him?

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: O Lord ſir, he went the wrong way, the fellow had
a faire commiſsion to the contrary. Sir, heere is his paſ-
port, I pray you ſir, we haue done him wrong.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: I warrant thee, giue it me.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: You will ſtand between the gallowes and me.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: I, I.

speech.speaker: Hang.
speech.line: I thank your L. worſhip.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: And yet though ſomewhat neerer me concernes,
I will to eaſe the greefe that I ſuſtaine,
Take truce with ſorrow while I read on this.

line.emph: My lord, I writ as mine extreames requirde,
That you would labour my deliuerie:
If you negleƈt my life is deſperate,
And in my death I ſhall reueale the troth.
You know my Lord, I ſlew him for your ſake,
And was confederate with the Prince and you,
Wonne by rewards and hopefull promiſes,

speech.line: I holpe to murder​Don Horatio too.
Holpe he to murder mine Horatio,
And aƈtors in th’accurſed Tragedie,
Waſt thou Lorenzo, Balthazar and thou,
Of whome my Sonne, my Sonne deſeru’d ſo well,
What haue I heard, what haue mine eies behelde?
O ſacred heauens, may it come to paſſe,
That ſuch a monſtrous and deteſted deed,
So cloſely ſmootherd, and ſo long conceald,
Shall thus by this be venged or reuealed.
Now ſee I what I durſt not then ſuſpeƈt,
That Bel-imperias Letter was not fainde,
Nor fained ſhe though falſly they haue wrongd,
Both her, my ſelfe, Horatio, and themſelues.
Now may I make compare twixt hers and this,
Of euerie accident, I neere could finde
Till now, and now I feelingly perceiue,
They did what heauen vnpuniſht would not leaue.
O falſe Lorenzo, are theſe thy flattering lookes?
Is this honour that thou didſt my Sonne?
And Balthazar bane to thy ſoule and me,
What this the ranſome he reſeru’d thee for?
Woe to the cauſe of these conſtrained warres,
Woe to thy baſenes and captiuitie,
Woe to thy birth, thy body and thy ſoule,
Thy curſed father, and thy conquerd ſelfe:
And band with bitter execrations be
The day and place where he did pittie thee.
But wherefore waſte I mine vnfruitfull words?
When naught but blood will ſatiſfie my woes:
I will goe plaine me to my Lord the King,
And cry aloud for iuſtice through the Court.
Wearing the flints with theſe my withered feet,
And either purchaſe iuſtice by intreats,
Or tire them all with my reuenging threats.

speech.speaker: Isa.
