speech.line: So that you ſay this hearb will purge the eye
And this the head, ah but none of them will purge the hart:
No, thers no medicine left for my diſeaſe,
Nor any phiſick to recure the dead:
Horatio, O wheres Horatio.

speech.speaker: Maide.
speech.line: Good Madam, aﬀright not thus your ſelfe,
With outrage for your ſonne Horatio.
He ſleepes in quiet in the Elizian fields.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: Why did I not giue you gownes and goodly things,
Bought you a whiſtle and a whipſtalke too:
To be reuenged on their villanies.

speech.speaker: Maid.
speech.line: Madame theſe humors doe torment my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: My ſoule, poore ſoule thou talkes of things
Thou knowſt not what, my ſoule hath ſiluer wings,
That mounts me vp vnto the higheſt heauens,
To heauen, I there ſits my Horatio,
Backt with troup of fiery Cherubins,
Dauncing about his newly healed wounds
Singing ſweet hymnes and chaunting heauenly notes,
Rare hermony to greet his innocence,
That dyde, I dyde a mirrour in our daies.
But ſay, where ſhall I finde, the men, the murderers,
That ſlew Horatio, whether ſhall I runne
To finde them out, that murdered my Sonne.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What meanes this outrage that is oﬀred me?
What am I thus ſequeſtred from the Court?
No notice, ſhall I not know the cauſe,
Of these my ſecret and ſuſpitious ils?
Accurſed brother, vnkinde murderer.
Why bends thou thus thy minde to martir me?
Hieronimo, why writ I of thy wrongs?
Or why art thou ſo ſlacke in thy reuenge?
Andrea, O Andrea, that thou ſaweſt,
Me for thy freend Horatio handled thus,
And him for me thus cauſeles murdered.
Wel, force perforce, I must conſtraine my ſelfe,
To patience, and apply me to the time,
Till heauen as I haue hoped ſhall ſet me free.

speech.speaker: Chriſ.
speech.line: Come Madame Bel-imperia, this may not be.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lorenzo, Balthazar and the Page.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Boy, talke no further, thus farre things goe well,
Thou art aſſurde that thou ſaweſt him dead?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Or els my Lord I liue not.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Thats enough.
As for this reſolution at his end,
Leaue that to him with whom he ſoiourns now.
Heere, take my ring, and giue it Christophill,
And bid him let my Siſter be enlarg’d,
And bring her hither ſtraight.
This that I did was for a policie,
To ſmooth and keepe the murder ſecret,
Which as a nine daies wonder being ore-blowne,
My gentle Siſter will I now enlarge.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: And time Lorenzo, for my Lord the Duke,
You heard enquired for her yeſter-night.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why? and my Lord, I hope you have heard me ſay,
Suﬀicient reaſon, why ſhe kept away.
But thats all one, my Lord, you loue her?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Then in your loue beware, deale cunningly,
Salue all ſuſpititons, onely ſooth me vp,
And if ſhe hap to ſtand on tearmes with vs,
As for her ſweet hart, and concealement ſo,
Ieſt with her gently, vnder fained ieſt
Are things concealde, that els would breed vnreſt.
But heere ſhe comes.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Now Siſter.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Siſter, no thou art no brother, but an enemy,
Els wouldſt thou not haue vſde thy Siſter ſo,
Firſt, to aﬀright me with thy weapons drawne,
And with extreames abuſe my company:
And then to hurry me like whirlwinds rage,
Amidſt a crew of thy confederates:
And clap me vp where none might come at me,
Nor I at any to reueale my wrongs.
What madding fury did poſſeſſe thy wits?
Or wherein iſt that I oﬀended thee?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Aduiſe you better Bel-imperia,
For I haue done you no disparagement:
Vnleſſe by more discretion then deseru’d,
I ſought to ſaue your honour and mine owne.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Mine honour, why Lorenzo, wherein iſt,
That I negleƈt my reputation ſo,
As you, or any need to reſcue it.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: His highnes and my Father were resolu’d,
To come conferre with olde Hieronimo,
Concerning certaine matters of eſtate,
That by the Viceroy was determined.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: And wherein was mine honour toucht in that?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Haue patience Bel-imperia, heare the reſt.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Me next in ſight as meſſenger they ſent,
To giue him notice that they were ſo nigh:
Now when I came conſorted with the Prince,
And vnexpeƈted in an Arbour there,
Found Bel-imperia with Horatio.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: How than?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why then remembring that olde diſgrace,
Which you for Don Andrea had indurde,
And now were likely longer to ſuſtaine,
By being found ſo meanely accompanied:
Thought rather, for I knew no readier meane,
To thruſt Horatio forth my fathers way.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: And carry you obſcurely ſome where els,
Leaſt that his highnes ſhould haue found you there.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Euen ſo my Lord, and you are witneſſe,
That this is true which he entreateth of.
You(gentle brother)forged this for my ſake,
And you my Lord, were made his instrument:
A worke of worth, worthy the noting too.
But whats the cauſe that you concealde me ſince?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Your melancholly Siſter ſince the newes,
Of your first fauorite Don Andreas death,
My Fathers olde wrath hath exaſperate.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: And better waſt for you being in diſgrace,
To abſent your ſelfe and giue his fury place.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: But why I had no notice of his ire?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: That were to adde more fewell to your fire.
Who burnt like Aetne for Andreas loſſe.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Hath not my Father then enquird for me?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Siſter he hath; and this excuſde I thee.
But Bel-imperia, ſee the gentle prince,
Looke on thy loue, beholde yong Balthazar,
Whose paſsions by the presence are increaſt,
And in whoſe melachollie thou maieſt see,
Thy hate, his loue: thy flight, his following thee.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Brother you are become an Oratour,
I know not I, by what experience,
Too politick for me, paſt all compare,
Since laſt I saw you, but content your ſelfe,
The Prince is meditating higher things.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Tis of thy beauty then that conquers Kings.
Of those thy treſſes Ariadnes twines,
Wherewith my libertie thou haſt ſurpriſde,
Of that thine iuorie front my ſorrowes map,
Wherein I see no hauen to reſt my hope.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: To loue and feare, and both at once my Lord,
In my conceipt, are things of more import,
Then womens wit are to be buſied with.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Tis I that loue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Whome?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: But that I feare.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Whome?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Feare your ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I brother.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: As thoſe, that what they loue, are loath, and feare to looſe.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Then faire, let Balthazar your keeper be.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No, Balthazar doth feare as well as we,

line.emph: Et tremulo metui pauidum iunxere timorem,

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Nay, and you argue things ſo cunningly,
Weele goe continue this diſcourſe at Court.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Led by the loadſtar of heauenly lookes,
Wends poore oppreſſed Balthazar,
As ore the mountains walkes the wanderer,
Incertain to eﬀeƈt his Pilgrimage.

scene.stagedir: Enter two Portingales and Hieronimo meets them.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: By your leaue Sir.

speech.speaker: Hier.
speech.line: Good leaue haue you, nay, I pray you goe,
For ile leaue you, if you can leaue me ſo.

scene.speech: 2 Pray you which is the next way to my L. the Dukes.s

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: The next way from me.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: To the houſe we meane.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: O hard by, tis yon houſe that you ſee.
You could not tell vs, if his Sonne were there?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Who, my Lord Lorenzo?

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: I Sir.

scene.stagedir: He goeth in at one doore and comes out at another.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Oh forbeare, for other talke for vs far fitter were.
But if you be importunate to know,
The way to him, and where to finde him out,
Then liſt to me, and ile reſolue your doubt,
There is a path vpon your left hand ſide,
That leadeth from a guiltie conſcience,
Vnto a forreſt of diſtruſt and feare.
A darkſome place and dangerous to paſſe,
There ſhall you meet with melancholy thoughts,
Whoſe balefull humours if you but vpholde,
It will conduƈt you to diſpaire and death:
Whoſe rockie cliﬀes when you haue once behelde,
Within a hugie dale of laſting night,
That kind’ed with the worlds iniquities,
Doth cast vp filthy and deteſted fumes.
Not far from thence where murderers haue built,
A habitation for their curſed ſoules:
There in a brazen Caldron fixed by Iove,
In his fell wrath vpon a ſulpher flame:
Your ſelues shall finde Lorenzo bathing him,
In boyling lead and blood of innocents.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha: why ha, ha, ha. Farewell good ha, ha, ha.
Doubtles this man is paſsing lunaticke,
Or imperfeſion of his age doth make him dote.
Come, lets away to ſeek my lord the Duke.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hieronimo with a Ponyard in one hand, and a Rope in the other.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Now Sir, perhaps I come and ſee the King,
The King ſees me, and faine would heare my ſute.
Why is this not a ſtrange and ſeld ſeene thing,
That ſtanders by with toyes ſhould ſtrike me mute.
Go too, I ſee their ſhifts, and ſay no more,
Hieronimo, tis time for thee to trudge.
Downe by the dale that flowes with purple gore,
Standeth a firie Tower, there ſits a iudge,
Vpon a ſeat of ſteele and molten braſſe:
And twixt his teeth he holdes a fire-brand,
That leades vnto the lake where hell doth ſtand.
Away Hieronimo to him be gone:
Heele doe thee iuſtice for Horatios death.
Turne down this path thou ſhalt be with him ſtraite,
Or this, and then thou needſt not take thy breth.
This way, or that way: ſoft and faire, not ſo:
For if I hang or kill my ſelfe, lets know
Who will reuenge Horatios murther then?
No, no, fie no: pardon me, ile none of that:
speech.stagedir: He flings away the dagger & halter.
speech.line: This way ile take, and this way comes the King,
And heere ile haue a fling at him thats flat.
And Balthazar ile be with thee to bring,
And thee Lorenzo, heeres the King, nay, ſtay,
And heere, I heere, there goes the hare away.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now ſhew Embaſſadour what our Viceroy ſaith,
Hath hee receiu’d the articles we ſent?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Iustice, O iustice to Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Back, ſeeſt thou not the King is buſie?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: O, is he ſo.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Who is he that interrupts our buſines?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Not I, Hieronimo beware, goe by, goe by.

speech.speaker: Embaſ.
speech.line: Renowned King he hath receiued and read,
Thy kingly proﬀers, and thy promiſt league,
And as a man exreamely ouer-ioyd
To heare his Sonne ſo Princely entertainde,
Whoſe death he had ſo ſolemnely bewailde,
This for thy further ſatiſfaƈtion,
And kingly loue, he kindely lets thee know:
Firſt, for the marriage of his Princely Sonne,
With Bel-imperia, thy beloued Neece,
The newes are more delightfull to his ſoule
Then myrrh or incenſe to the oﬀended heauens.
In perſon therefore will be come himſelfe,
To ſee the marriage rites ſolemnized,
And in the preſence of the Court of Spaine,
To knit a ſure inexecrable band,
Of Kingly loue, and euerlaſting league,
Betwixt the Crownes of Spaine and Portingale.
There will he giue his Crowne to Balthazar,
And make a Queene of Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brother, how like you this our Vice-roies loue?

speech.speaker: Caſt.
speech.line: No doubt my Lord, it is an argument
Of honorable care to keepe his freend,
And wondrous zeale to Balthazar, his ſonne?
Nor am I leaſt indebted to his grace,
That bends his liking to my daughter thus.

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Now laſt(dread lord)heere hath his highnes ſent,
Although he ſend not that his Sonne returne,
His ranſome doe to Don Horatio.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Horatio, who cals Horatio?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And well remembred, thank his Maieſtie.
Heere, ſee it giuen to Horatio.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Iuſtice, O iuſtice, iuſtice, gentle King.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Who is that? Hieronimo?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Iuſtice, O iuſtice, O my ſonne, my ſonne,
My Sonne whom naught can ranſome or redeeme.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Hieronimo, you are not well aduiſde.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: A way Lorenzo, hinder me no more,
For thou haſt made me bankrupt of my bliſſe:
Giue me my ſonne, you shall not ranſome him.
Away, ile rip the bowels of the earth,
And Ferrie ouer th’Elizian plaines,
And bring my ſonne to ſhew his deadly wounds.
Stand from about me, ile make a pickaxe of my poniard,
And heere ſurrender vp my Marshalſhip:
For Ile goe marſhall vp the feends in hell,
To be auenged on you all for this.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What means this outrage? will none of you re-
ſtraine his fury?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Nay ſoft and faire, you ſhall not need to ſtriue,
Needs muſt he goe that the diuels driue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What accident hath hapt Hieronimo?
I haue not ſeene him to demeane him ſo.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My gratious Lord, he is with extreame pride,
Conceiued of yong Horatio his Sonne,
And couetous of hauing himſelfe,
The ranſome of the yong Prince Balthazar.
Diſtraƈt and in a manner lunatick.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Beleeue me Nephew we are ſorie fort,
This is the loue that Fathers beare their ſonnes:
But gentle brother, goe giue to him this golde,
The Princes raunſome, let him haue his due;
For what he hath Horatio ſhall not want,
Happily Hieronimo hath need thereof.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: But if he be thus helpleſly diſtraƈt,
Tis requiſite his oﬀice be reſignde,
And giuen to one of more diſcretion.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We ſhall encreaſe his melanchollie ſo.
Tis beſt that we ſee further in it firſt:
Till when our ſelfe will exempt the place.
And Brother, now bring in the Embaſſador,
That he may be a witnes of the match,
Twixt Balthazar and Bel-imperia,
And that we may prefixe a certaine time,
Wherein the marriage ſhalbe ſolemnized,
That we may haue thy lord the Vice-roy heere.

speech.speaker: Em.
speech.line: Therein your highnes highly ſhall content,
His Maieſtie, that longs to heare from hence.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: On then, and heare you Lord Embaſſadour.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hieronimo with a book in his hand.

line.foreign: Vindiƈta mihi.

speech.line: I, heauen will be reuenged of euery ill,
Nor will they suſſer murder vnrepaide:
Then ſtay Hieronimo, attend their will,
For mortall men may not appoint their time.

line.emph: Per ſcelus ſemper tutum eſt ſceleribus iter.

speech.line: Strike, and ſtrike home, where wrong is oﬀred thee,
For euils vnto ils conduƈtors be.
And death’s the worſt of reſolution.
For he that thinks with patience to contend,
To quiet life, his life ſhall eaſily end.

line.foreign: Fata ſi miſeros iuuant habes ſelutem:
Fata ſi vitam negant, habes ſepulchrum.

speech.line: If destinie thy miseries doe ease,
Then hast thou health, and happie shalt thou be;
If deſtinie thy miſeries doe eaſe,
Then haſt thou health, and happie ſhalt thou be:ſ
If deſtinie denie thee life Hieronimo.
Yet ſhalt thou be aſſured of a tombe:
If neither, yet let this thy comfort be,
Heauen couereth him that hath no buriall,
And to conclude, I will reuenge his death,
But how? not as the vulgare wits of men,
With open, but ineuitable ils:
As by a ſecret, yet a certaine meane,
Which vnder kindeſhip wilbe cloked beſt.
Wiſe men will take their opportunitie,
Cloſely and ſafely fitting things to time:
But in extreames aduantage hath no time.
And therefore all times fit not for reuenge:
Thus therefore will I reſt me in vnreſt,
Diſſembling quiet in vnquietnes.
Not ſeeming that I know their villanies:
That my ſimplicitie may make them think,
That ignorantly I will let all ſlip,
For ignorance I wot, and well they know,

line.foreign: Remedium malorum iners est.

speech.line: Nor ought auailes it me to menace them,
Who as a wintrie ſtorme vpon a plaine,
Will beare me downe with their nobilitie.
No, no, Hieronimo, thou muſt enioyne
Thine eies to obſeruation, and thy tung
To milder ſpeeches then thy ſpirit aﬀoords,
Thy hart to patience, and thy hands to reſt,
Thy Cappe to cutteſie, and thy knee to bow,
Till to reuenge thou know when, where, and how.
How now, what noiſe, what coile is that you keepe?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Heere are a ſort of poore Petitioners,
That are importunate and it ſhall pleaſe you ſir,
That you ſhould plead their caſes to the King.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: That I should plead their ſeuerall aƈtions,
Why let them enter, and let me ſee them.

scene.stagedir: Enter three Citizens and an olde Man.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: So I tell you this for learning and for law,
Theres not any aduocate in Spaine,
That can preuaile, or will take halfe the paine,
That he will in purſuite of equitie.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Come neere you men that thus importune me,
Now muſt I beare a face of grauitie,
For thus I vſde, before my Marſhalſhip,
To pleide the cauſes as Corrigedor. —
Come on ſirs, whats the matter?
Sir an Aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Of Batterie?

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: Mine of debt.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Giue place.
No ſir, mine is an aƈtion of the caſe.
Mine an Eieƈtionae firma by a Leaſe.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Content you ſirs; are you determined,
That I ſhould plead your ſeuerall aƈtions?

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: I ſir, and heeres my declaration.
And heere is my band.
And heere is my leaſe.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: But wherefore ſtands you ſilly man ſo mute,
With mournfall eyes and hands to heauen vprearde?
Come hether father, let me know thy cauſe.

speech.speaker: Senex.
speech.line: O worthy ſir, my cause but slightly knowne,
May mooue the harts of warlike Myrmydons,
And melt the Corſicke rockes with ruthfull teares.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Say Father, tell me whats thy ſute?

speech.speaker: Senex.
speech.line: No ſir, could my woes
Giue way vnto my moſt diſtreſfull words,
Then ſhould I not in paper as you ſee,
With incke bewray, what blood began in me.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Whats heere? the humble ſupplication
Of Don Bazulto for his murdred ſonne.

speech.speaker: Senex.
speech.line: I Sir.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: No ſir, it was my murdred ſonne, oh my ſonne.
My sonne, oh my sonne Horatio.
But mine, or thine, Bazulto, be content.
Heere, take my hand-kercher and wipe thine eies,
Whiles wretched I, in thy miſhaps may ſee,
The liuely portraiƈt of my dying ſelfe.
speech.stagedir: He draweth out a bloudie Napkin.
speech.line: O no, not this, Horatio this was thine.
And when I dyde it in thy deereſt blood,
This was a token twixt thy ſoule and me
That of thy death reuenged I ſhould be.
But heere, take this, and this! what my purſe?
I this and that, and all of them are thine,
For all as one are our extremeties.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: Oh, ſee the kindenes of Hieronimo.
This gentlenes ſhewes him a Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: See, ſee, oh ſee thy ſhame Hieronimo,
See heere a louing Father to his ſonne:
Beholde the ſorrowes and the ſad laments,
That he deliuereth for his ſonnes diceaſe.
If loues eﬀeƈts so striues in lesser things,
If loue enforce ſuch moodes in meaner wits,
If loue expreſſe such power in poor eſtates,
Hieronimo, When as a raging Sea,
Toſt with the winde and tide ore turneſt then
The vpper-billowes courſe of waues to keep,
Whileſt leſſer waters labour in the deepe.
Then ſhameſt thou not Hieronimo to negleƈt
The ſweet reuenge of thy Horatio.
Though on this earth iuſtice will not be found:
Ile downe to hell and in this paſsion,
Knock at the diſmall gates of Plutos Court,
Getting by force as once Alcides did,
A troupe of furies and tormenting hagges,
To torture Don Lorenzo and the reſt.
Yet leaſt the triple headed porter ſhould,
Denye my paſſage to the ſlimy ſtrond:
The Thracian poet thou ſhalt counterfeite:
Come on olde Father be my Orpheus,
And if thou canſt no notes vpon the Harpe,
Then ſound the burden of thy ſore harts greefe,
Till we do gaine that Proſerpine may graunt,
Reuenge on them that murdred my Sonne.
Then will I rent and teare them thus and thus,
Shiuering their limmes in peeces with my teeth.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: Oh ſir my Declaration.
Saue my bond.
Saue my bond.
Alas my leaſe, it coſt me ten pound,
And you my Lord haue torne the ſame:

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: That can not be, I gaue it neuer a wound,
Shew me one drop of bloud fall from the ſame:
How is it poſsible I ſhould ſlay it then,
Tuſh no, run after, catch me if you can.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but the olde man.
Bazulto remaines till Hieronimo enters againe, who
speech.line: And art thou come Horatio from the depth,
To aske for iuſtice in this vpper earth?
To tell thy Father thou art vnreueng’d,
To wring more teares from Iſabellas eies?
Whoſe lights are dimd with ouer-long laments.
Goe back my ſonne, complaine to Eacus,
For heeres no iuſtice, gentle boy, be gone.
For iuſtice is exiled from the earth:
Heronimo will beare thee company:
Thy mother cries on righteous Radamant,
For iuſt reuenge againſt the murderers.

speech.speaker: Senex.
speech.line: Alas my L. whence ſprings this troubled ſpeech?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: But let me looke on my Horatio:
Sweet boy how art thou chang’d in deaths black ſhade?
Had Proſerpine no pittie on thy youth?
But ſuﬀered thy fair crimſon colourd ſpring,
With withered winter to be blaſted thus?
Horatio, thou are older then thy Father:
Ah ruthleſſe Father, that fauour thus transformess.

speech.speaker: Ba.
speech.line: Ah my good Lord, I am not your yong Sonne.

speech.speaker: Hie.
speech.line: What, not my Sonne, thou then, a furie art,
Sent from the emptie Kingdome of blacke night,
To ſummon me to make appearance:
Before grim Mynos and iuſt Radamant,
To plague Hieronimo that is remiſſe,
And ſeekes not vengeance for Horatioes death.

speech.speaker: Ba.
speech.line: I am a greeued man and not a Ghoſt,
That came for iuſtice for my murdered Sonne.

speech.speaker: Hie.
speech.line: I, now I know thee, now thou nameſt thy Sonne,
Thou art the liuely image of my griefe,
Within thy face, my ſorrowes I may ſee.
The eyes are gum’d with teares, thy cheekes are wan,
Thy forehead troubled, and thy muttring lips
Murmure ſad words abruptly broken oﬀ,
By force of windie ſighes thy ſpirit breathes,
And all this sorrow riſeth for thy Sonne:
And ſelfe ſame ſorrow feele I for my Sonne.
Come in old man, thou ſhalt to Izabell,
Leane on my arme, I thee, thou me ſhalt ſtay,
And thou and I, and ſhe will ſing a ſong:
Three parts in one, but all of diſcords fram’d,
Talke not of cords, but let vs now be gone,
For with a cord Horatio was ſlaine.

scene.stagedir: Enter King of Spaine, the Duke, Vice-roy, and Lorenzo,

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Go Brother it is the Duke of Caſtiles cauſe, ſalute the
Vice-roy in our name.

speech.speaker: Caſtile.
speech.line: I go.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Go forth Don Pedro, for thy Nephews ſake,
And greet the Duke of Castile.

speech.speaker: Pedro.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And now to meet theſe Portaguiſe,
For as we now are, ſo ſometimes were theſe,
Kings and commanders of the weſterne Indies.
Welcome braue Vice-roy to the Court of Spaine,
And welcome all his honorable traine:
Tis not vnknowne to vs, for why you come,
Or haue ſo kingly croſt the Seas:
Suﬀiſeth it in this we note the troth,
And more then common loue you lend to vs.
So is it that mine honorable Neece,
For it beſeemes vs now that it be knowne,
Already is betroth’d to Balthazar:
And by appointment and our condiſcent,
To morrow are they to be married.
To this intent we entertaine thy ſelfe,
Thy followers, their pleaſure, and our peace:
Speak men of Portingale, ſhall it be so?
If I, ſay ſo: if not, ſay flatly no.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Renowned King, I come not as thou thinkſt,
With doubtfull followers, vnreſolued men,
But ſuch as haue vpon thine articles,
Confirmed thy motion and contented me.
Know ſoueraigne, I come to ſolemnize
The marriage of thy beloued Neece,
Faire Bel-imperia with my Balthazar.
With thee my Sonne, whom ſith I liue to ſee,
Heere take my Crowne, I giue it her and thee,
And let me liue a ſolitarie life,
In ceaſeleſſe praiers,
To think how ſtrangely heauen hath thee preſerued.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: See brother, ſee how nature ſtriues in him,
Come worthy Vice-roy and accompany
They freend, with thine extremities:
A place more priuate fits this princely mood.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Or heere or where your highnes thinks it good.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Caſ. and Lor.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Nay ſtay Lorenzo, let me talke with you,
Seeſt thou this entertainement of theſe Kings?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I doe my Lord, and ioy to ſee the ſame.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: And knoweſt thou why this meeting is?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: For her my Lord, whom Balthazar doth loue,
And to confirme their promiſed marriage.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: She is thy Siſter?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Who Bel-imperia, I my gratious Lord
And this is the day, that I haue longd ſo happily to see.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Thou wouldſt be loath that any fault of thine,
Should intercept her in her happines.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Heauens will not let Lorenzo erre ſo much.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Why then Lorenzo liſten to my words:
It is ſuſpeƈted and reported too,
That thou Lorenzo wrongſt Hieronimo,
And in his ſutes toward his Maieſtie,
Still keepſt him back and ſeekes to croſſe his ſute.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: That I my Lord?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I tell thee Sonne my ſelfe haue heard it ſaid,
When to my ſorrow I haue been aſhamed
To anſwere for thee, though thou art my ſonne.
Lorenzo, knoweſt thou not the common loue,
And kindenes that Hieronimo hath wone,
By his deſerts within the Court of Spaine?
Or ſeeſt thou not the K. my brothers care,
In his behalfe, and to procure his health?
Lorenzo, ſhouldſt thou thwart his paſsions,
And hee exclaime againſt thee to the King,
What honour wert in this aſſembly,
Or what a ſcandale were among the Kings,
To heare Hieronimo exclaime on thee.
Tell me, and looke thou tell me truely too,
Whence growes the ground of this report in Court.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My L. it lyes not in Lorenzos power,
To ſtop the vulgar liberall of their tongues:
A ſmall aduantage makes a water breach,
And no man liues that long contentethall.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: My ſelfe haue ſeene thee buſie to keep back,
Him and his ſupplications from the King.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Your ſelfe my L. hath ſeene his paſsions,
That ill beſeemde the preſence of a King,
And for I pittied him in his diſtreſſe,
I helde him thence with kinde and curteous words,
As free from malice to Hieronimo,
As to my ſoule my Lord.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Hieronimo my ſonne, miſtakes thee then,

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My gratious Father, beleeue me ſo he doth,
But whats a ſilly man diſtraƈt in minde.
To think vpon the murder of his ſonne:
Alas how eaſie is it for him to erre?
But for his ſatiſfaƈtion and the worlds,
Twere good my L. that Hieronimo and I,
Were reconcilde, if he miſconſter me.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Lorenzo thou haſt ſaid, it ſhalbe ſo,
Goe one of you and call Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Come Bel-imperia, Balthazars content,
My ſorrowes eaſe, and ſoueraigne of my bliſſe,
Sith heauen hath ordainde thee to be mine:
Diſperce thoſe cloudes and melanchollie lookes,
And cleere them vp with thoſe thy Sunne bright eies,
Wherein my hope and heauens faire beautie lies.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: My lookes my Lord, are fitting for my loue,
Which new begun, can ſhew brighter yet.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: New kindled flames ſhould burne as morning Sun.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: But not too faſt, leaſt heate and all be done.
I ſee my Lord my Father.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: True my loue, I will goe ſalute him.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Welcome Balthazar, welcome braue Prince,
The pledge of Caſtiles peace:
And welcome Bel-imperia, how now girle?
Why commeſt thou ſadly to ſalute vs thus?
Content thy ſelfe for I am ſatisfied,
It is not now as when Andrea liu’d,
We haue forgotten and forgiuen that,
And thou art graced with a happeir loue.
But Balthazar heere comes Hieronimo.
Ile haue a word with him.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: And wheres the Duke?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Yonder.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Euen ſo: what new deuice haue they deuised tro?
Pocas Palabras, milde as the Lambe,
Iſt I will be reueng’d? no, I am not the man.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Welcome Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Welcome Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Welcome Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: My Lords I thank you for Horatio.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Hieronimo, the reaſon that I ſent
To ſpeak with you, is this.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What, ſo ſhort?
Then ile be gone, I thank you fort:

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Nay, ſtay Hieronimo, goe call him ſonne.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Hieronimo, my father craues a word with you.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: With me ſir? why my L. I thought you had done.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: No, would he had.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Hieronimo I hear you finde your ſelfe agreeued at my Sonne
Becauſe you haue not acceſſe vnto the Kiing,
And ſay tis he that intercepts your ſutes.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Why, is not this a miſerable thing my Lord?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Hieronimo, I hope you haue no cauſe,
And would be loth that one of your deſerts,
Should once haue reaſon to ſuspeƈt my Sonne,
Conſidering how I think of you my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Your ſonne Lorenzo, whome, my noble Lord?
The hope of Spaine, mine honorable freend?
Graunt me the combat of them, if they dare.
Ile meet them face to face to tell me ſo.
Theſe be the ſcandalous reports of ſuch,
As loues not me, and hate my Lord too much.
Should I suspeƈt Lorenzo would preuent,
Or croſſe my ſute, that loued my Sonne ſo well?
My Lord, I am aſhamed it ſhould be ſaid.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Hieronimo, I neuer gaue you cauſe.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: My good Lord, I know you did not.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: There then pauſe, and for the ſatiſfaƈtion of the world,
Hieronimo frequent my homely houſe,
The Duke of Caſtile Ciprians ancient ſeat,
And when thou wilt, vſe me, my ſonne, and it:
But heere before Prince Balthazar and me
Embrace each other, and be perfeƈt freends.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: I marry my Lord, and ſhall:
FreendsƑ quoth he ) ſee, Ile be freends with you all.
Specially with you my louely Lord,
For diuers causes it is fit for vs,
That we be freends. The world is suspitious,
And men may think what we imagine not.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Why this is freendly doone Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: And that I hope olde grudges are forgot.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What els, it were a ſhame it ſhould not be ſo.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Come on Hieronimo at my requeſt,
Let vs entreat your company to day.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Awake Eriƈtho, Cerberus, awake,
Sollicite Pluto gentle Proſerpine,
To combat Achinon and Ericus in hell.
For neere by Stix and Phlegeton:
Nor ferried Caron to the fierie lakes,
Such fearfull ſights, as poore Andrea ſee?
Reuenge awake.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Awake, for why?

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Awake Reuenge, for thou art ill aduiſde,
Thſleepe, away, what thou art warnd to watch.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Content thy ſelfe, and doe not trouble me.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Awake Reuenge, if loue as loue hath had,
Haue yet the power or preuailance in hell,
Hieronimo with Lorenzo is ioynde in league,
And intecepts our paſſage to reuenge:
Awake Reuenge, or we are woe degone.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Thus worldings ground what they haue dreamd vpon,
Content thy ſelfe Andrea, though I ſleepe,
Yet is my mood ſoliciting their ſoules,
Suﬀiceth thee that poore Hieronimo,
Cannot forget his ſonne Horatio.
Nor dies Reuenge although he ſleepe a while,
For in vnquiet, quietnes is faind:
And ſlumbring is a common worldly wile.
Beholde Andrea for an inſtance how,
Reuenge hath ſlept, and then imagine thou,
What tis to be ſubieƈt to deſtinie.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Awake Reuenge, reueale this miſterie.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: The two firſt the nuptiall Torches boare,
As brightly burning as the mid-daies ſunne:
But after them doth Himen hie as faſt,
Clothed in ſable, and a Saﬀron robe,
And blowes them out, and quencheth them with blood,
As diſcontent that things continue ſo.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Suﬀiceth me thy meanings vnderſtood,
And thanks to thee and thoſe infernall powers,
That will not tollerate a Louers woe,
Reſt thee for I will ſit to ſee the reſt.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Then argue not for thou haſt thy requeſt.

speech.speaker: Bel-imperia.
speech.line: Is this the loue that bearſt Horatio?
Is this the kindnes that thou counterfeits,
Are theſe the fruits of thine inceſſant teares?
Hieronimo, are theſe thy paſsions?
Thy proteſtations, and thy deepe laments,
That thou wert wont to wearie men withall.
O vnkinde Father, O deceitfull world,
With what excuſes canſt thou ſhew thy ſelfe?
With what diſhonour, and the hate of men:
Thus to negleƈt the loſſe and life of him,
Whom both my letters, and thine owne beliefe,
Aſſures thee to be cauſeles ſlaughtered.
Hieronimo, for ſhame Hieronimo:
Be not a Hiſtory to after times,
Of ſuch ingratitude vnto thy Sonne.
Vnhappy Mothers of ſuch children then,
But monſtrous Fathers, to forget ſo ſoone
The death of thoſe, whom they with care and coſt
Haue tendred ſo, thus careles ſhould be loſt.
My ſelfe a stranger in respeƈt to thee,
So loued his life as ſtill I wiſh their deathes,
Nor ſhall his death be vnreuengd by me.
Although I beare it out for faſhions ſake:
For heere I ſweare in ſight of heauen and earth,
Shouldſt thou negleƈt the loue thou ſhouldſt retaine,
And giue it ouer and deuiſe no more,
My ſelfe ſhould ſend their hatefull ſoules to hel,
That wrought his downfall with extreameſt death.

speech.speaker: Hie.
speech.line: But may it be that Bel-imperia
Vowes ſuch reuenge as ſhe hath dain’d to ſay:
Why then I ſee that heauen applies our drift,
And all the Saints doe ſit ſoliciting
For vengeance on thoſe curſed murtherers
Madame tis true, and now I find it ſo,
I found a letter, written in your name,
And in that letter, how Horatio died.
Pardon, O pardon, Bel-imperia,
My feare and care in not beleeuing it,
Nor thinke, I thoughtles thinke vpon a meane,
To let his death be vnreuenge’d at full,
And heere I vow, ſo you but giue conſent,
And will conceale my reſolution,
I will ere long determine of their deathes,
That cauſles thus haue murderd my Sonne.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Hieronimo, I will conſent, conceale,
And ought that may eﬀeƈt for thine auaile,
Ioyne with thee to reuenge Horatios death.

speech.speaker: Hier.
speech.line: On then, whatſoeuer I deuiſe,
Let me entreat you grace my praƈtiſes,
For why, the plots already in mine head,
Heere they are.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: How now Hieronimo, what, courting Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: I my Lord, ſuch courting as I promiſe you
She hath my hart, but you my Lord haue hers.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: But now Hieronmimo, or neuer we are to intreate your helpe.

speech.speaker: Hie.
speech.line: My help, why my good Lords aſſure your ſelues of me
of me;
For you haue giuen me cauſe, I by my faith haue you.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: It pleaſde you at the entertainment of the Embaſſa-dour
embassadour,
To grace the King ſo much as with a ſhew,
Now were your ſtudie so well furniſhed,
As for the paſsing of the firſt nights ſport,
To entertaine my Father with the like:
Or any ſuch like pleaſing motion,
Aſſure yourſelfe it would content them well.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Is this all?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I, this is all.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Why then ile fit you, ſay no more.
When I was yong I gaue my minde,
And plide my ſelfe to fruitles poetrie:
Which though it profite the profeſſor naught,
Yet is it paſsing pleaſing to the world.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: And how for that?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Marrie my good Lord thus.
And yet me thinks you are too quick with vs.
When in Tolledo there I ſtudied,
It was my chaunce to write a tragedie,
See heere my Lords.
Which long forgot, I found this other day,
Nor would your Lordſhips fauour me ſo much,
As but to grace me with your aƈting it,
I meane each one of you to play a part,
Aſſure you it will proue moſt paſing ſtrange,
And wondrous plauſible to that aſſembly.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: What would you haue vs play a Tragedie?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Why Nero thought it no diſparagement,
And Kings and Emperours haue tane delight,
To make experience of their wit in plaies?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Nay be not angry good Hieronimo,
The Prince but aſked a queſtion.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: In faith Hieronimo and you be in earneſt,
Ile make one.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: And I another.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Now my good Lord, could you intreat,
Your sister Bel-imperia, to make one,
For whats a play without a woman in it?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Little intreaty ſhall ſerue me Hieronimo,
For I muſt needs be imployed in your play.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Why this is well, I tell you Lordings,
It was determined to haue beene aƈted,
By Gentlemen and ſchollers too,
Such as could tell what to ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: And now it ſhall be plaide by Princes and Courtiers,
ſuch as can tell how to ſpeak:
If as it is our Country manner,
You will but let vs know the argument.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: That ſhall I roundly: the Cronicles of Spaine
Recorde this written of a Knight of Rodes,
He was betrothed and wedded at the length,
To one Perſeda an Italian dame.
Whoſe beauty rauished all that her behelde,
Especially the ſoule of Soliman,
Who at the marriage way the cheefeſt gueſt.
By ſundry meanes ſought Soliman to winne,
Perſedas loue, and could not gaine the ſame.
Then gan he break his paſsions to a freend,
One of his Baſhaw whom he held full deere,
Her had this Bashaw long ſolicited,
And ſaw ſhe was not otherwiſe to be wonne,
But by her huſbands death this Knight of Rodes.
Whome preſently by trecherie he ſlew.
She ſtirde with an exceeding hate therefore,
As cauſe of this ſlew Soliman.
And to eſcape the Baſhawes tirannie,
Did ſtab her ſelfe, and this the Tragedie.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: O excellent.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: But ſay Hieronimo what then became of him
That was the Baſhaw?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Marrie thus, moued with remorſe of his miſdeeds,
Ran to a mountain top and hung himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: But which of vs is to performe that part,

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: O that will I my Lords, make no doubt of it,
Ile play the murderer I warrant you,
For I already haue conceited that.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: And what ſhall I.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Great Soliman the Turkiſh Emperour.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: And I.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Erastus the Knight of Rhodes,

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: And I.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Perſeda, chaſte and reſolute.
And heere my Lords are ſeueral abſtraƈts drawne,
For eache of you to note your partes,
And aƈt it as occasion’s oﬀred you.
You muſt prouide a turkiſh cappe,
A black muſtacio and a fauchion.
You with a croſſe like to a Knight of Rhodes.
And Madame, you muſt attire your ſelfe,
Like Phoebe, Flora, or the huntreſſe,
Which to your diſcretion ſhall ſeeme beſt,
And as for me my Lords Ile looke to one,
And with the raunſome that the Vice-roy ſent
So furniſh and performe this tragedie,
As all the world ſhall ſay Hieronimo,
Was liberall in gracing of it ſo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Hieronimo, me thinks a Comedie were better.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: A Comedie, fie, comedies are fit for common wits
But to preſent a Kingly troupe withall,
Giue me a ſtately written Tragedie.
Tragedia cother nato, fitting Kings,
Containing matter, and not common things.
My Lords, all this muſt be perfourmed,
As fitting for the firſt nights reuelling.
The Italian Tragedians were ſo ſharpe of wit,
That in one houres meditation,
They would performe any thing in aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: And well it may, for I haue ſeene the like
In Paris, mongſt the French Tragedians.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: In Paris, mas and well remembered,
Theres one thing more that reſts for vs to doo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Whats that Hieronimo forget not any thing.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Each one of vs muſt aƈt his parte
In vnknowne languages,
That it may breede the more varietie.
As you my Lord in Latin, I in Greeke,
You in Italian, and for becauſe I know,
That Bel-imperia hath praƈtiſed the French,
In courtly French ſhall all her phraſes be.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: You meane to trye my cunning then Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: But this will be a meere confuſion,
And hardly ſhall we all be vnderſtoode.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: It muſt be ſo, for the concluſion
Shall proue the inuention and all was good:
And I my ſelfe in an Oration,
That I will haue there behinde a curtaine,
And with a ſtrange and wondrous ſhew beſides:
Assure your ſelfe ſhall make the matter knowne.
And all ſhalbe concluded in once Scene,
For theres no pleaſure tane in tediouſnes.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: How like you this?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Why thus my Lord, we must reſolue,
To ſoothe his humors vp.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: On then Hieronimo, farewell till ſoone.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Youle plie this geere.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Why ſo, now ſhall I ſee the fall of Babilon,
Wrought by the heauens in this confuſion.
And if the world like not this tragedie,
Hard is the hap of olde Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Isa.
speech.line: Tell me no more, O monſtrous homicides.
Since neither pietie nor pittie moues
The King to iuſtice or compaſsion:
I will reuenge my ſelfe vpon this place,
Where thus they murdered my beloued Sonne.
Downe with theſe branches and these loathsome bowes,
On this vnfortunate and fatall pine.
Downe with them Iſabella, rent them vp,
And burnes the roots from whence the reſt is ſprung:
I will leaue not a root, a ſtalke, a tree,
A bowe, a branch, a bloſſome, nor a leafe,
Not, not a hearb within this garden Plot
Accurſed complot of my miſerie,
Fruitleſſe for euer may this garden be.
Barren the earth, and bliſleſſe whoſoeuer,
Immagines not to keep it vnmanurde:
An Eaſterne winde comixt with noiſome aires,
Shall blaſt the plants and yong ſaplings,
The earth with Serpents ſhalbe peſtered,
And paſſengers for feare to be infeƈt,
Shall ſtand aloofe, and looking at it, tell
There murdred dide the ſonne of Iſabell.
I heere he dide, and heere I him imbrace,
See where his Ghoaſt ſolicites with his wounds,
Reuenge on her that ſhould reuenge his death,
Hieronimo, make haſte to ſee thy ſonne,
For ſorrow and diſpaire hath ſcited me,
To heare Horatio plead with Radamant.
Make haſte, Hieronimo to holde excuſde,
Thy negligence in purſute of their deaths,
Whoſe hatefull wrath bereu’d him of his breath.
Ah nay, thou doſt delay their deaths,
Forgiues the murderers of thy noble ſonne,
And none but I beſtirre me to no end,
And as I curſſe this tree from further fruit,
So ſhall my wombe be curſed for his ſake,
And with this weapon will I wound this breſt,
That haples breſt that gaue Horatio ſuck.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hieronimo, he knocks up the curtaine.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: How now Hieronimo wheres your fellows,
That you take all this paine?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: O ſir, it is for the Authors credit
To look that all things may goe well:
But good my Lord let me intreat your grace,
To giue the King the coppie of the plaie:
This is the argument of what we ſhew.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I will Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: One more thing my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Whats that?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Let me intreat your grace,
That when the traine are paſt into the gallerie,
You would vouchſafe to throwe me downe the key.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I will Hieronimo.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What are you ready Balthazar?
Bring a chaire and a cuſhion for the King.
Well doon Balthazar, hang vp the title.
Our ſcene is Rhodes, what is your beard on?

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Halfe on, the other is in my hand.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Diſpatch for ſhame, are you ſo long?
Bethink thy ſelfe Hieronimo,
Recall thy wits, recompt thy former wrongs,
Thou haſt receiued by murder of thy ſonne,
And laſtly, not leaſt, how Iſabell;
Once his mother and thy deereſt wife:
All woe begone for him hath ſlaine her ſelfe.
Behoues thee then Hieronimo to be reueng’d.
The plot is laide of dire reuenge,
On then Hieronimo purſue reuenge,
For nothing wants but aƈting of reuenge.

scene.stagedir: Enter Spaniſh King, Vice-roy, the Duke of Caſtile,

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Viceroy, ſhall we ſee the Tragedie,
Of Soliman the Turkiſh Emperour:
Performde by pleaſure by yor Sonne the Prince,
My Nephew Don Lorenzo, and my Neece.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Who, Bel-imperia?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, and Hieronimo our Marſhall.
At whoſe requeſt they deine to doo’t themſelues.
Theſe be our paſtimes in the Court of Spaine.
Heere brother, you ſhall be the booke-keeper.
This is the argument of that they ſhew.

scene.stagedir: Gentlemen, this play of Hieronimo in ſundrie Languages was thought good to be ſet downe in Engliſh more largely, for the eaſier vnderſtanding to euery publique Reader.

speech.speaker: Balthazar.
speech.line: Baſhaw, that Rhodes is ours, yeeld heauens the honor,
And holy Mahhomet our ſacred Prophet:
And be thou grac’t with euery excelence,
That Soliman can giue or thou deſire.
But thy deſert in conquering Rhodes is leſſe,
Then in reſeruing this faire Chriſtian Nimph,
Perſeda, blisfull lamp of Excellence:
Whoſe eies compell like powerfull Adamant,
The warlike heart of Soliman to wait.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: See Vice-Roy, that is Balthazar your Sonne,
That repreſents the Emperour Solyman
How well he aƈts his amorous paſsion.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: I Bel-imperia hath taught him that.

speech.speaker: Caſtile
speech.line: That’s becauſe his mind runnes al on Bel-imperia.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What euer ioy earth yeelds betide your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Earth yeelds no ioy without Perſedaes loue.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Let then Perſeda on your grace attend.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: She ſhall not wait on me, but I on her.
Drawne by the influence of her lights, I yeeld.
But let my friend the Rhodian knight come foorth,
Eraſto, dearer then my life to me,
That he may see Perſeda my beloued.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Heere comes Lorenzo, looke vpon the plot,
And tell me brother what part plaies he?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Ah my Eraſto, welcome to Perſeda.

speech.speaker: Lo.
speech.line: Thrice happie is Eraſto, that thou liueſt,
Rhodes loſſe is nothing to Eraſtoes ioy:
Sith his Perſeda liues, his life ſuruiues.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Ah Bashaw, heere is loue betweene Eraſto
And faire Perſeda ſoueraigne of my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Remooue Eraſto mighty Solyman,
And then Perſeda will be quickly wonne.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Eraſto is my friend, and while he liues,
Perſeda neuer will remooue her loue.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Let not Eraſto liue, to greeue great Soliman.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Deare is Eraſto in our Princly eye.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: But if he be your riuall, let him die.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: VVhy let him die, ſo loue commaundeth me.
Yet greeve I that Eraſto ſhould ſo die.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Eraſto, Solyman ſaluteth thee,
And lets thee wit by me his highnes will:
VVhich is, thou ſhouldſt be thus imploid.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Ay me Eraſto, see Solyman Eraſtoes ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Balt.
speech.line: Yet liueth Solyman to comfort thee.
Faire Queene of beautie, let not fauour die,
Both with gratious eye beholde his griefe,
That with Perſedaes beautie is encreaſt,
If by Perſeda griefe be not releaſt.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Tyrant, desist ſoliciting vaine sutes,
Relentles are mine eares to thy laments,
As thy butcher is pittileſſe and baſe,
VVhich ſeazd on my Eraſto, harmeleſſe knight.
Yet by thy power thou thinkeſt to commaund,
And to thy power Perſeda doth obey:
But were ſhe able thus ſhe would reuenge
Thy treacheries on thee ignoble Prince:
And on herſelfe she would be thus reuengd.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: VVell ſaid olde Marſhal, this was brauely done.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: But Bel-imperia plauies Perſeda well.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: were this in earneſt Bel-imperia,
You would be better to my Sonne then ſo.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But now what followes for Hieronimo?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Marrie this followes for Hieronimo.
Heere breake we oﬀ our ſundrie languages,
And thus conclude I in our vulgare tung.
Happely you think, but bootles are your thoughts,
That this is fabulouſly counterfeit,
And that we doo as all Tragedians doo.
To die to day, for (faſhioning our scene)
The death of Aiax, or some Romaine peer,
And in a minute starting vp againe,
Reuiue to please to morrows audience.
No Princes, know I am Hieronimo,
The hopeles Father of a haples Sonne,
Whose tung is tun’d to tell his lateſt tale,
Not to excuſe groſſe errors in the play.
I ſee your lookes vrge inſtance of theſe words,
Beholde the reaſon vrging me to this,
See heere my ſhew, look on this ſpeƈtacle:
Heere lay my hope, and heere my hope hath end:
Heere lay my hart, and heere my hart was ſlaine:
Heere lay my treaſure, heere my treaſure loſt:
Heere lay my bliſſe, and heere my bliſſe bereft.
But hope, hart, treaſure, ioy and bliſſe:
All fled, faild, died, yea, all decaide with this.
From forth theſe wounds came breath that gaue me life,
They murdred me that made theſe fatall markes:
The cauſe was loue, whence grew this mortall hate.
The hate, Lorenzo and yong Balthazar:
The loue, my ſonne to Bel-imperia.
But night the couerer of accurſed crimes,
With pitchie ſilence huſht theſe traitors harmes,
And lent them leaue, for they had ſorted leaſure,
To take aduantage in my Garden plot,
Vpon my Sonne, my deere Horatio:
There mercileſſe they butcherd vp my boy,
In black darke night, to pale dim cruell death.
He ſhrikes, I heard, and yet me thinks I heare,
His diſmall out-cry eccho in the aire:
With ſooneſt ſpeed I haſted to the noiſe,
Where hanging on a tree, I found my ſonne.
Through girt with wounds, and ſlaughtred as you ſee,
And greeued I ( think you ) at this ſpeƈtacle?
Speak Portaguiſe, whoſe loſe reſembles mine,
If thou canſt weep vpon thy Balthazar,
Tis like I wailde for my Horatio.
And you my L. whoſe reconciled ſonne,
Marcht in a net, and thought him ſelfe vnſeene,
And rated me for a brainſicke lunacie,
With “God amend that mad Hieronimo
How can you brook our plaies cataſtrophe?
And heere beholde this bloudie hand-kercher,
Which at Horatios death I weeping dipt,
Within the riuer of his bleeding wounds.
It as propitious, ſee I haue reſerued,
And neuer hath it left my bloody hart,
Soliciting remembrance of my vow.
With theſe, O theſe accurſed murderers,
Which now perform’d, my hart is ſatiſfied.
And to this end the Baſhaw I became,
That might reuenge me on Lorenzos life,
Who therefore was appointed to, the part,
And was to repreſent the Knight of Rhodes,
That I might kill him more conueniently.
So ſice-roy was this Balthazar thy Sonne,
That Soliman, which Bel-imperia,
In perſon of Perſeda murdered, —
Solie appointed to that tragicke part,
That ſhe might ſlay him that oﬀended her.
Poore Bel-imperia miſt her part in this,
For though the ſtory ſaith ſhe ſhould haue died,
Yet I of kindenes, and care for her,
Did otherwiſe determine of her end.
But loue of him whome they did hate too much
Did vrge her reſolution to be ſuch.
And Princes now beholde Hieronimo,
Author and aƈtor in this Tragedie:
Bearing his lateſt fortune in his fiſt:
And will as rſsolute conclude his parte,
As any of the Aƈtors gone before.
And Gentles, thus I end my play,
Vrge no more words, I haue no more to ſay.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O hearken Vice-roy, holde Hieronimo,
Brother, my Nephew and thy Sonne are ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: We are betraide, my Balthazar is ſlaine,
Breake ope the doores, runne ſaue Hieronimo.
Hieronimo, doe but enforme the King of theſe euents,
Ypon mine honour, thou ſhalt haue no harme.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Vice-roy, I will not truſt thee with my life,
Which I this day haue oﬀered to my Sonne:
Accurſed wretch, why ſtaieſt thou him that was reſolued to die?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Speak traitor, damned, bloudy murderer ſpeak,
For now I haue thee I wil make thee ſpeak:
Why haſt thou done this vndeſeruing deed?

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Why haſt thou murdered my Balthazar?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Why haſt thou butchered both my children thus?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: O good words, as deare to me was Horatio,
As yours, or yours my L. to you.
My guitles Sonne was by Lorenzo ſlaine,
And by Lorenzo and that Balthazar,
Am I at laſt reuenged thorowly.
Vpon whoſe ſoules may heauens be yet auenged,
With greater far then theſe aﬀliƈtions.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: But who were thy confederates in this?

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: That was thy daughter Bel-imperia.
For by her hand my Balthazar was ſlaine, —
I ſaw her ſtab him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why ſpeakeſt thou not?

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: What leſſer libertie can Kings aﬀoord
Then harmles ſilence? then aﬀord it me:
Suﬀiceth I may not, nor I will not tell thee.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Fetch forth the tortures.
Traitor as thou art, ile make thee tell.

speech.speaker: Hiero.
speech.line: Indeed thou maieſt torment me as his wretched Sonne
Hath done in murdring my Horatio.
But neuer ſhalt thou force me to reueale,
The thing which I haue vowed inviolate:
And therefore in deſpight of all thy threats,
Pleaſde with their deaths, and eaſde with their reuenge:
Firſt take my tung, and afterwards my hart.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O monſtrous reſolution of a wretch,
See Vice-Roy, hee hath bitten foorth his tung,
Rather than to reueale what we requirde.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Yet can he write.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And if in this he ſatisfie vs not,
We will deuiſe the ’xtreamest kinde of death,
That euer was inuented for a wretch.

scene.stagedir: Then he makes ſignes for a knife to mend his pen.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: O he would haue a knife to mend his Pen.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: Here and aduiſe thee that thou write the troth, —
Looke to my brother, ſaue Hieronimo.

scene.stagedir: He with a knife ſtabs the Duke and himſelf.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What age hath euer heard ſuch monſtrous deeds?
My brother and the whole ſucceeding hope,
That Spaine expeƈted after my diſceaſe,
Go beare his body hence that we may mourne,
The loſſe of our beloued brothers death.
That he may be entom’d, what ere befall,
I am the next, the neereſt, laſt of all.

speech.speaker: Vice.
speech.line: And thou Don Pedro do the like for vs,
Take vp our haples ſonne vntimely ſlaine:
Set me vp with him, and he with wofull me,
Vpon the maine maſt of a ſhip vnmand,
And let the winde and tide hall me along,
To Sillas barking and vntamed greefe:
Or to the lothſome poole of Archeron,
To weepe my want for my sweet Balthazar.
Spaine hath no refuge for a Portingale.

stagedir.emph: The Trumpets ſound a dead march, the King of Spaine mourning after his brothers body, and the King of Portingale bearing the body of his Sonne.

speech.speaker: Ghoaſt.
speech.line: I, now my hopes haue end in their eﬀeƈts,
When blood and ſorrow finnish my deſires:
Horatio murdered in his Fathers bower,
Vilde Serberineby Pedringano ſlaine,
Falſe Pedringano hang’d by quaint deuice,
Faire Iſabella by her ſelfe miſdone,
Prince Balthazar by Bel-imperia ſtabd,
The Duke of Caſtile an his wicked Sonne,
Both done to death by olde Hieronimo.
My Bel-imperia falne as Dido fell,
And good Hieronimo ſlaine by himſelfe:
I theſe were speƈtacles to pleaſe my ſoule.
Now will I beg at louely Proſerpine,
That by the vertue of her Princely doome,
I may conſort my freends in pleaſing ſort,
And on my foes work iuſt and ſharpe reuenge.
Ile lead my freend Horatio through thoſe feeldes,
Where neuer dying warres are ſtill inurde.
Ile lead faire Iſabella to that traine,
Where pittie weepes but neuer feeleth paine.
Ile lead my Bel-imperia to thoſe ioyes,
That veſtal Virgins and faire Queenes poſſeſſe;
Ile lead Hieronimo where Orpheus plaies,
Adding ſweet pleaſure to eternall daies.
But ſay Reuenge, for thou muſt helpe or none,
Againſt the reſt how ſhall my hate be ſhowne?

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: This hand ſhall hale them down to deepeſt hell,
Where none but furies, bugs and tortures dwell.

speech.speaker: Ghoaſt.
speech.line: Then ſweet Reuenge doo this at my requeſt,
Let me iudge and doome them to vnreſt.
Let looſe poore Titius from the vultures gripe,
And let Don Ciprian ſupply his roome,
Place Don Lorenzo on Ixions wheele,
And let the louers endles paines ſurceaſe:
Iuno forgets olde wrath and graunts him eaſe.
Hang Balthazar about Chimeras neck,
And let him there bewaile his bloudy loue,
Repining at our ioyes that are aboue.
Let Serberinegoe roule the fatall ſtone,
And take from Siciphus his endles mone.
False Pedringaeo for his trecherie,
Let him be dragde through boyling Acheron,
And there liue dying ſtill in endles flames,
Blaſpheming Gods and all their holy names.

speech.speaker: Reuenge.
speech.line: Then haſte we downe to meet thy freends and foes,
To place thy freends in eaſe, the reſt in woes.
For heere, though death hath end their miſerie,
Ile there begin their endles Tragedie.
